The hero cornered Satan in his castle and charged to kill, only to have Satan open up a portal to escape with his right hand man, Alciel.

Their plan went horribly wrong, however. Somehow Satan and Aciel ended up in Tokyo Japan and stripped of their powers, becoming human! With no way of regaining the magic that they lost they are forced to live as humans, getting jobs and an apartment.


This show is comedy from start to finish, making me laugh until the very last moment. It relies heavily on character interaction, name calling, and miscommunication. There is some action thrown into the mix, but I think the show was truly made to be a comedy.


The show seems episodic, but as more characters and background are introduced we see a plot forming, filled with antagonists that want to destroy Satan's bike and ruin his perfect attendance record at McRonald's (not really, but I don't want to spoil anything). 


There are 13 episodes, but the story really concludes at 12, with the 13th shows what happens the next day, and ends on a comedic note. I know others have been disappointed with the ending, and I would be lying if I said that the ending didn't bother me. However, the last episode sort of suggests that there could be a second season. There hasn't been any talk of a sequel yet, but a girl can hope, right?


Art: 8/10

The characters are cute, especially the girls. The guys look pretty standard, with nothing standing out too much in their character design beside eye and hair color. But the boys don't really matter, it's all about the ladies. The art style suggests to me that the animators were leaning towards something like moe. But I can't be too sure. The backgrounds are beautiful, especially in Ente Isla; and it compliments the character designs well. The color is bright and cheery, utilizing a wide array of color schemes. Even the darker scenes are rich with color. This sort of color technique has been pretty standard in the industry for a few years, but such vibrance is more common in 'moe', cute anime (which is another reason why I think this is the direction the animators wanted to go with).

The animation is smooth and consistent, but the fight scenes are nothing special. This is okay because the show is more about comedy, rather than action.


Sound: 8/10

I'm giving sound an 8 purely for the English voice acting. Now I know there will be sub diehards that will snuff me for watching dubs (although I love subs too), but I have watched the show in both English and Japanese. Both are good, but I think that the dub better picks up on the emotion of the characters, and definitely catches the bickering between the characters better. In my opinion it's better than the original Japanese voice actors, and without it I probably wouldn't have enjoyed the show as much.

The music in the anime was nothing special, and I barely paid attention to it unless they decided to cut the music all together. The opening theme grew on me, and I ended up listening to it for every episode. I really disliked the ending theme however, and never listened to it after the second episode. 


Character: 9/10

I absolutely love all of the characters. All of them are just very exaggerated and theatrical, which is so counter intuitive in the human world that they seem eccentric to normal humans. It's perfect because they try to blend in with normal humans, but if they get excited it all gets thrown out the window.

But what I really like is how Satan and Emelia the hero interact. For the longest time, they justify their actions due to their respective roles (Satan = evil, Emelia = hero). But we see that Satan has an easier time throwing away his role and becoming, dare I say, nice. Emelia has a harder time letting go of her role, but she eventually does. It shows that anyone can change, which is a pretty nice message coming from the king of demons.


Enjoyment: 9/10

I'm not really a comedy fan, but I truly enjoyed this show. There was enough plot to keep my interest. And while the characters were exaggerated, their human struggles were very real; and as a college student I can sympathize with their poor as dirt life styles.


Overall: 8/10

Overall I give this show two thumbs up! Seriously, give this show a try. You don't even have to watch the dub (although I recommend it if you speak English), just give it a try. It's sort of a hidden gem, filled with comedy gold. Once you finish it, you'll want a second season as well.

Hataraku Maou-sama! is a great 13 episode adaptation of the two light novels it is based off of, with many others yet to be animated. But they need to be animated! This adaptation, though short, managed itself very well and produced great comedy, adventure, character development, etc. 
Now here is my review of Hataraku Maou-sama!- A typical comedy, or an ingenious character-driven story. Or perhaps something else? Read to understand what I have understood from this anime.
Story: 8.2
The story of Hataraku Maou-sama! is relatively simple, centered around the Demon King Satan, who upon his defeat to the Hero Emilia Justina, is forced to flee tomodern day Tokyo. With a quick introduction set right after his defeat, one has to wonder how and where this anime gets its name. This is all explained when the story is revealed to have Satan, now a human known as Maou Sadao, working at a MgRonalds. But where could a story, now centered around a fast-food chain take us? Well, almost everywhere but it. Without revealing the story, most of the episodes are self-contained, and as a result characters are introduced very quickly and become part of the adventures and misadventures of Sadaou and Ashiya, his loyal general. Enilia, now Emi Yusa, also becomes part of the story, as she observes and investigates Sadao at every chance, no matter who he is with and where he goes, whether it be a fight or his house. Though there are a few episodes centered around the fast-food chain, as well as an overall motivation for Madao to seize power through use of the food chain, the anime doesn't cover  anything too serious in its adaptation, seeing as it is only based on two of the novels, and leaves the door open for a second season. With an okay ending to a great adaptation, the story receives an 8.2 in my book.


Art: 8.7

The art in this show is amazing! The color seems to match well with the very diverse surroundings, such as the simple and small apartment of Madao and Ashiya, the call center where Emi Yusa works, the MgRonalds where Madao works, and the overall surrounding of Tokyo. The character interactions are very well done, especially in instances of comedy, as the character expressions are supreme in quality. The action scenes do not disappoint, blending the color, magic and semi-human fighting scenes to a great level. To be frank, the final fight was very well done, but as the final episode of the show, it seemed to lack the detail and refinement in animation of the first major fight, mostly due to the night setting, but was great nonetheless.


Sound: 8.8

The sound in Hataraku Maou-sama! is just a tad bit better than its art. The OP and ED songs are all very nice, but the actual show and characters are wonderful. With a variety of characters from Ente Isla, the world from which the main characters escaped from, as well as several from Earth, the voice actors are considerably well chosen, and definitely nail their characters, especially during their over-reactions. Sound during the more intense scenes are very well done as well, as the fights are both meaningful and fulfilling when couple with the good audio. White Fox did a really good job in 2013 with this adaptation in terms of art and sound.


Character: 10.0

YES! The best part of this show! Hataraku Maou-sama! has some of the best comedy in all of anime, let alone anime of 2013, and there can't be amazing comedy with hilarious characters. For Maou, his humor comes from his more relaxed way of experiencing life on Earth, as well as his fiery determination to rule Japan through MgRonalds. Some of his funniest scenes come from his sudden character change from demon to human, as he proudly displays his earned money and promotion to Ashiya. Ashiya probably has to have the best humor out of the whole group. His interactions when he first arrives with Maou are ingenious, and his later interactions with Maou and their combined living conditions is hilarious. Once Chiho, Emi Yusa, Rika, Kamazuki and especially Lucifer, who goes by Urushira, all meet and interact with Ashiya, the variety of comedic sequences that come as a result are both outstanding and very well crafted. Emi Yusa herself has her fair share of comedy, with her well known internet meme with her and Chiho, and her interactions with Maou, which find her in a difficult state of disbelief and anger. With great characters for this episodic adaptation, Hataraku Maou-sama! earns a 10.0 for characters.


Enjoyment: 9.3

Overall, for me, this series was both surprising and refreshing. After delving in more darker anime such as Psycho Pass, the pure comedy and intense character interactions were both startling and awesome. I was disappointed that this was only 13 episodes in length, but I am pretty pleased Hataraku Maou-sama! is growing ever more popular, as Viz Media just licensed the series and is releasing the first light novel in North America April 21, 2015. Hopefully I can enjoy this series even more if White Fox dcides to adapt teh second season after completing Akame Ga Kill. Till then, I am very happy with my experience with this anime.


Overall: 9.1

Overall, Hataraku Maou-sama! hits all of its goals very well. With an interesting story, great character interactions, intense comedy and overall themes of magic, change, and the real world, Hataraku Maou-sama! is a great anime for anyone off any age to watch. Till we get a second season, Hataraku Maou-sama! is a near-perfect comedy anime to watch. Hope you all enjoyed my review!

Hataraku Maou-sama!, or The Devil is a Part Timer!, is an anime that's been on my list for a while, thanks to it's interesting concept, but I'd just never had the drive to start because I was wrapped up with something else. Sitting around bored yesterday, I decided to start it, as I saw it on Netflix, and figured why not. I am so, so glad I decided to take the plunge into the hilarity that is The Devil is a Part-Timer!, because quite simply this anime was amazing. It is easily the funniest anime I have seen, and one of the funniest things thatI've watched in general.


Story: 7

The very first thing I heard about this anime was its absolutely ridiculous concept; the devil and his right hand man appear on Earth after escaping a large battle in their native land, Ente Isla, and have to adapt to life in Japan. They do so by renting a one room apartment, and the devil gets a part time job at the local MgRonalds, while the right hand man, Alziel, plays housewife. This gets crazy as they make human friends and other characters from the mystical land of Ente Isla come to Earth to hunt them down, and everything spirals from here.


This concept is executed unbelievably well. The story was interesting, and the way different characters played off of one another to advance their development, and the story, was an absolute joy to watch. Humor, drama, and slice of life (to a degree) were all mixed together and pulled off without a hitch. 


Well, almost without a hitch. As much as I loved the plot and concepts, I feel as though certain components could have been improved. Yeah, we got some cool backstory about Ente Isla and the characters while they were there, but I wish they had delved a bit more into that. The war-torn land these characters originated from seems like it could have been explained more, and while I enjoyed the flashbacks, I just wish there had been more (either from a longer season, or second season). Yes, I understand that this story is primarily about these characters adapting to Earth, but that leads into my second problem; I feel as though certain actions and relationships shown on Earth were slightly abrupt and would have gone over better had we been given a more in-depth introduction to them ahead of time (or even after, to help clear it up). But, all in all, the flashbacks that are there are great, and the main part of the story, their shenanigans on Earth, are very interesting and I was definitely invested in seeing what happened next.


Art: 9

The art is great. The animation for the characters looks very good, and the battle scenes were always a pleasure to watch. The bright colors of Earth contrasted the darker, muddier palette used for Ente Isla, much like how humans and the hero had a brighter feel to them while the demons (well, at least when they looked demonic) were dark. When the art shifts were used, they were definitely appropriate and well placed, as they definitely conveyed the feelings and tone for the different characters and locations quite well, and each character was undoubtably designed just how I would have imagined them.


Sound: 9

First things first, the OP is awesome. Really, really awesome. The song is great, catchy, and memorable, and the accompanying art is also great. The OST isn't something I honestly picked up on much at first, but as I got more invested I definitely noticed it and find it to be very well done. Both the battle scenes and casual hang out/humor filled scenes had great music going along with them. Finally, the voice acting was also top notch (both the sub and dub). Personally, I would recommend watching this in your native language if possible, as I feel that for a comedy, you should hear the jokes and inflections on the character's lines fluently rather than reading at a different speed than the lines are delivered; what's the fun reading a joke before they finish saying it? In addition, some of the subs for jokes aren't quite as funny, because the jokes will be adjusted in the dub to flow better than a sub would allow. If you really desire to go subbed, then by all means go for it as the sub and original Japanese VAs are great, though I would really suggest at least giving the dub a shot. I think the english dub was really good, and every VA actually put their all into it which resulted in some great punchlines and deliveries. 


My one negative for sound is that I was not a big fan of the ED. I really liked the art, but something about the song seemed off to me. Don't get me wrong, I think it fit with the tone of the show and the accompanying art, but I just wasn't much of a fan.


Character: 9

This is another part where The Devil is a Part-Timer! really shines. I LOVED the cast of characters. The protagonists were perfect; as previously stated, the art/animation and VAs for each character were exactly what I would have wanted, and the characters themselves were all relatable, hilarious, and experienced genuine growth. The villains were also great, and I loved the way a certain one changed after his big battle. There was one character I didn't particularly like for a couple episodes, but even that was resolved by the end. Ashiya was my favorite, but really I could see there being endless arguments about which character is best because they're just all so lovable and entertaining. This is a cast I wholeheartedly want to see more of, and I'll certainly remember their crazy shenanigans for quite some time. I really can't put into words how much I genuinely enjoyed this cast.


My one criticism of the characters is that there are two who are introduced, would seem to be important, and then basically entirely disappear for the remainder of the season. There is not mention or explanation of them, which was a little disappointing. They're even in the OP with the other main characters, and I feel like they don't have a place there because they're so uninvolved and not really important to the story. 


Enjoyment: 10

Despite some previously mentioned issues, like an underdeveloped backstory and two characters seeming out of place, I thoroughly enjoyed The Devil is a Part-Timer!. The humor was consistently funny and had me bursting out laughing multiple times, the cast is amazing, the art/animation and sound are both great, and the concept and resulting situations the characters get into are a riot. I would wholeheartedly recommend this not only to people who like anime, but also people who like comedy. I will without a doubt be purchasing the bluray collection and hope to see a season 2 sometime soon, as I want to go back into this world. Anyone looking for a truly great anime should be quite pleased with The Devil is a Part-Timer!.


Overall: 9/10


To the helpful and not helpful voters, feedback is appreciated!

Somewhere in another world the Demon King is about to become ruler of the entire world, but he is stopped by the hero and is forced to live in Japan. Start comedy of the Spring 2013 season.
This shows main draw is the characters. Just about all of them are exceptionally entertaining, even the ones that tend me be kind of annoying have some truly hilarious moments, especially when you add in their facial expressions.
Many watchers will be pleased by the fact that they show never really goes into full out harem. Although each girl has some level of feelings for the MC, they vary basedon their background with him.


I mean obviously the show is a social dialogue on the state of the economy where the great demon king Satan (Sadao) has to work at a McRonalds in order to scrap together rent. Well, maybe that's stretching it a bit. But part of what makes the show great is the setting that it's put in.


The early episodes are clearly better than the ones in the middle. This is kind of problematic because there is a slight decline in quality throughout the series until you get to the ending (which are really good episodes). The comedy is still there and it's still very entertaining, but the funniest character is essentially sidelined. This is not to say the episodes are not bad, they are actually pretty good, but it's like the difference from an A to a B.


The animation is well done and on closer examination looks kind of like a more polished Katanagatari based on how the colors are done and such.


If you want a unique comedy with entertaining characters look no further than this show. It's one of the best that Spring 2013 had to offer.

If I should thank anyone it will be Netflix bc that is where I watched this. When I saw this on there I knew I was going to watch it eventually and when I did I ended up watching it all the way in one day and in eng dub. Thank god for it being good.
Well the story is Sadao, basically Satan, with his 2nd in command, Ashiya,  go to Earth Tokyo, of course, after beating narrowly beaten in their homeworld by the hero and the forces of good, then tries to gain power there, though he is working as a part timer ata parodied McDonalds and trying to rise in the ranks there till eventual takeover of the world... omg I just realized how Invader Zim that sounds. Anyways, they are not alone as other members of their world comes to Earth as well including the hero, Emilia, who tries to figure out the reason as to why Sadao doesn't just evil it up in this world like he did before.


The design of the characters are pretty stellar to me, nothing about them really got on my nerves and even the background no name characters were honestly good to look at. A few of my favs are Ashiya, James er I mean Sarue, and Suzuno. As for how the characters are, just get in there, watch the anime, see if your personality allows you to like them like mine does.


Sound and enjoyment are pretty top since I never skipped either op or ed and the ost is something I need to hear more of on youtube.


On a side note, that seal punch Sadao did on Lucifer was just amazing in execution.

Fun to watch, easy going, bit more action

I really liked the idea: a demon lord who fails to take over his world end up in modern Tokyo and has to live a normal human life. I liked the series, watched them in two days and when i finished episode 13 and wanted to go to the next one i was disappointed that there weren't more. Hope they make a season 2!

When I read the synopsis for Maou-sama, I sincerely hoped I was in for something special.
In some spectacularly fun ways, I was.
Above all else, Maou-sama is a sitcom, driven by bizarre satire and wacky situations made crazier by the clash of incompatible and fairly inflexible personalities. Right from the get go, I was entertained immensely, and you will be as well, though the more familiar you are with classic RPG tropes, the funnier. Given my longstanding love for the genre, seeing the old fantasy traditions turned upside down as "protagonist hero" and "antagonist overlord" alongside their companions are flung into sanitized modern Japanese society asfish out of water was a breath of fresh air. A superb first episode is dramatic, silly, and instantly engaging. The titular demon lord, Maou, in particular, is a beaming whiplash of a character, who never ceases to bring a smile to everyone's face (besides him or in the audience). Most of the primary characters are lovable goofs in one way or another, and it's hard not to laugh as they stumble all over themselves across disaster and daily routine. There's a backstory that crucial as well, and it kept me pondering when there weren't jokes tickling me.


Sadly, this anime--however loaded with potential--never quite steps up to its promise. Provided, there are laughs aplenty throughout, and the silly characters never stop being silly, but they fail to rise above a superficial interpretation of the tropes they set out to subvert, and development grinds to a halt. The first five episodes make bounding leaps of narrative progress, establishing the setting and maximizing its usage, introducing and exploring likable characters, punching my funny bone with fresh humor, defeating expectations, stirring up tension and resolving conflict... and ultimately coming to a conclusion for the narrative arc. So then I thought, Wow, so much in 5 episodes! If it keeps pace this will be one hell of a packed 13 episode series! Can't wait to see what's next!


As it turns out, not much, actually. 


After episode 5, nothing noteworthy happens in terms of story development, character relationships, conflicts or humor as devious as before. Being a 2-volume adaptation of an ongoing light novel series that is 11 volumes and counting, I understand the limitations yet can't help but sense that the anime had simultaneously been held back by its source material. Had the back 8 episodes moved as nimbly on all fronts as the first 5, the story could easily have concluded in self-containment. It would have been one of the greats of recent times. Instead, we get more of the same humor as before (which is still funny but increasingly repetitive), less screentime and interaction devoted to the most compelling relationship of all--the one between demon lord and heroine (giving way to lesser characters), and dead-end situations that are hit or miss in terms of hilarity. 


At points the show sinks to generic situations where I question whether or not I am watching YET ANOTHER tight-friends-group-slice-of-life-with-integrated-harem-plus-beach-episode-show. Primary characters will fire constant pot-shots at each other's tropes, and though novel at first, there is a strange disconnect between their awareness of their supposed roles and their actions. As much as the cast likes to reference their old traditions, they are surprisingly quick to adapt to the new surroundings and customs, making them too comfortable too soon, and thus less interesting. The two sides are quick to adapt to each other as well, fitting into new anime tropes, making me wonder if they view their previously life-defining alignments as no more than say, a grade-school feud.  Perhaps they band together because they are all strangers in a strange land, but even within their own world they surely must come from vastly different backgrounds... yet so little culture shock and discovery of differing habits between them is happening. Are you telling me when the forces of darkness and the crusaders of the church sit together to eat, they interact exactly like high school students who grew up together? How... disappointing (incidentally, this exchange is something Gargantia did exceptionally well and should be followed). If I wanted to see that I could have watched many other anime out there.


What irks me as well is how little the demon lord and heroine interact over the course of the show, with Emilia (the heroine) eventually getting as much screen time as any other support character, or all of them just meshing into group activity. I understand that this is the Maou demon lord show --and boy does he put one up-- but the priorities shifted in the wrong direction. What is more potentially tantalizing than more interaction between role models of good and evil in the ol' fantasy sense flipped on their morally grey head with a hint of sexual tension thrown in? As much as the other characters can entertain (especially the two generals of Maou), they are stock anime characters who do not necessarily struggle or embody the epicenter of the ancient world turned upside down, and do not have backstories I am nearly as curious about. The writers seem to know this --that the plot and development between leads has been throttled by the novels-- and so the story ends in a teasing way that evokes how it began, while hinting at things to come. 


If I seem overly negative towards this show, that's only because I had such high hopes, and for the first five episodes, those hopes were fulfilled and lead me to thirst for more. The premise is just so ripe, the characters so endearing, and so much fun was delivered, even now I wish to find out what happened and read all 11 of the untranslated novels. If you keep your expectations in check, you will find much to love here. Amusing at its worst, and brilliant at its best, Hataraku Maou-sama is definitely worth a watch.

Gonna keep this short and sweet.
The story is hilarious. The ruler of a Demon world is resorting to working part-time at McDonalds to even survive. I often looked back and laughed at how poor of a situation he's in, for an Overlord.
The art was good. Nothing to spectacular, but definitey not poor either.
I particularly liked the opening theme. Background music sounds good and fits well.
Ah, the characters. They're all enjoyable. One thing I don't quite understand though is how the Demons don't retain some of their Demonic ways. However, I thought this could be due to the influence of living a human life instead ofa Demon. Which makes sense to me, but I wish it would've cleared up more in the anime on their adaption to the Human world on earth.


VERY few series keep me interested throughout the whole season, and this definitely did that, while other series kinda feel like a drag when it comes to half of the season. There wasn't a moment where I was bored of this show.


Overall I think it's the enjoyment of the show that counts at the overall score. I almost gave it a nine, but seeing how much I enjoyed it, I had to give it a ten. I highly recommend this anime to anyone looking for a solid good comedy anime. Watch it.

So, this is my first review in this site, i do however have some experience in the reviewing area, mostly in other subjects like movies,  games and sports, but i thought i would give a shot with one of my other passions, animes.
 I decided to go with hataraku maou sama (hms for short) because it was the last anime i finished watching, so lets get started shall we ?
Story (9/10)
The plot in hataraku, although may seem as a cliche, regular story at first glance, (specially if this first glance is just reading the anime summary) its actually pretty original. Sure it has thecharacters we are used to see, the demons versus angels/mankind thing, and love couples we can see from a mile away, but thats not where hataraku brilliance lies, what hms does, and very well, is take all these cliches scenarios and add to them a completely crazy unexpected twist, making the viewer laugh his ass off in the process, for example, how could someone ever picture a Maou working at mcdonalds ? i mean its just outrageous to think of it, and thats exactly what makes it so funny.


Art (8/10)


The art in hataraku is pretty good, good character design and all... of course is no masterpiece but it does its job good enough.


Sound (7/10)


The sound in hms is ok... nothing flashy, no memorable soundtrack or anything like that, but its good enough. The opening song is cool, i will not download it to my iphone but i still could sit throug it without complains, the same goes for the ending, which is actually really sweet by the way, specially combined with that nice set of Chiho images.


Character (9/10)


This is where hatraku really shines in my opinion, again we do have some cliche characters, like Chiho, but despite their being a bit annoying at some points its nothig unbearable. Luckily these dull characters are more than compensated by some terrific characters like Lucifer (be honest, do you really thought that when he showed up for the first time, looking all bad ass and evil he would turn out the way he did ?), Maou itself, who is a good lead character for a change, and of course my favorite one, the brilliant Ashiya, by far for me the best character from last season, everytime this guy stepped on the scene i couldnt stop laughing, congrats for the outstanding voice acting by Yuuki Ono.


Enjoyment (9/10)


Hataraku Maou-sama ! was a delightful anime to watch, i got sad when it got over, and i really hope to see a continuation soon, the comedy was top quality, and the plot got interesting near the end, i'm sure it can develop even more if given the chance.


Overall (8.5/10)


One of the best animes in the last season, got me tottaly by surprised, and hooked me up from the first episode to the last, I definetly recomend it if you are looking for a light hearted comedy, with some pinches of action.

Story7: It is not too unusual. As a matter of fact I really laughed when I saw this and its synopsis. XD Yeah it is like so familiar to a hentai I just read called Power Play by the godly Yamatogawa about a demon lord who was forced to retreat with his faithful sidekick.  Into what is known as the human world. In there, he cannot use his powers so he had to adjust with his new life. But they were not the only ones who went there. As the person who almost defeated him followed him there. Yeah a funny start. Imagine SATANworking as an employee McDonalds LOL! The only thing you hate about this is the awaiting of the next season. Because this is a light novel and it is relatively short.


Art 8: White Fox who brought you Steins;Gate and the widely awaited Akame ga Kill. Expect clean and consistent animation. 


Sound 7 : Nothing special but it gets the job done during dramatic scenes


Character 9: I was really amazed on Maou as he progressd in the story. He was known as the demon lord in his world but he became Maou Sadao and became a normal person with a normal job. His ways have changed or maybe not as he was just forced to change. He is so badass even when he is in his human form. His sidekick's loyalty to him should also be highlighted as his reactions are so funny. 


Enjoyment 10: It was shortlived because it was only 13 episodes. I really enjoyed it and deviated it from the hentai manga Power Play. I really had no problems regarding with its enjoyment factor.


Overall 9: I know some people dont like it because it is so generic but it does entertain you but remember that you dont have to get too attached to it because you will hope for a second season just like me XDD

This REVIEW is the review of all the REVIEWS out there for this anime.
P.S-Read the synopsis first. This does not contain any type of story but it'll give you the answer to the question of WHY?
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 There are 3 rules of reviewing-
First rule- No anime is shit
Second rule-No anime is shit
Third rule-No anime is shit
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
It is based on the following parameters--
1)What is good about it?
2)(Probability of)Whom'll the anime appeal to?
3)Questions that other reviews raised in your head.
P.S.-If you don't want to read the whole, read the summary at the end of every question.
======================================
1)What is good about it?
  As a regular watcher of anime, Ican vouch of the good premise it offers. The setting set is intriguing and hilarious itself. 


  It is stupid. Yes, the fact that it is stupid makes it better. There are a lot of things wrong in it if you measure it with your logic meter but if you just watch it for fun it may also become one of your favorites.


  The comedy. As given its genre, the show's main feature is comedy which is similar to almost all others in the same genre.


  It is not serious. Now this is questionable that this is a good point but still I'll put it here anyway. People are more interested in gore and action packed stuff, now this here is a light show with some action and more reasoning.


---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


 Summary: Mild but good action with regular but well timed comedy with a carefree interesting premise.


---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


2)Whom'll the anime appeal to?

  There are many type of anime watchers--casual ones, picky ones, serious ones, fanboys/girls and other brats. Here the question is to who'll the anime appeal? 


  If you know what type of watcher you're let me make it easier for you. It is not the most logical or realistic anime(like most ones), so if you tend to find (too much) reason in the things you watch you might wanna skip it. But if you want to pass your time carefree you jump right into it.     


  Appealing is a spontaneous thing and there is not any particular said reason behind it. So there is not any surety, but we can still consider the possibility of it. 


---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


 Summary: If you find concept of appealing weird or wrong you should go ahead (Probability=1) but if not try and decide for yourself.(0<Probability<=1)


---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


3)Questions that other reviews raised in your head.

  *Overrated--Yes it is. But it doesn't matter it is still a fun show.

  *Stupid--I too said it is stupid but that is what it makes it what it is.

  *Fanbase and anti fanbase --No need to say anything.



---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


 Overall Summary-

Story-9/10

Art-9/10

Sound-8/10

Character-9/10

==========

||Overall-9/10||    

==========


---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


Any questions and criticisms are welcomed.

I'm going to start by saying that, while HMS is not the most amazing anime you will ever watch, it very quickly became one of my favorites for one simple reason: it made me laugh. It's not uncommon for some anime series to make me snort or giggle occasionally, but this one had me laughing out loud the entire time I watched it, sometimes even to the point that my stomach hurt.
I think the biggest critique on the series is the seemingly unfinished storyline, which is a perfectly fair complaint. There's a lot of backstory that goes unexplained, a lot of holes in the plot,and the characters seem to be missing important traits that their history indicates they should have (e.g. the Devil conqueror isn't all that evil, and the hero who supposedly hates him doesn't regard him with much of a grudge). I would have loved to see it explore the darker parts of the story and go truly in-depth with the characters and their histories, but that would have taken away from the lighteartedness of it.


The other aspects of it are fairly... Average. The art style is attractive but not amazing, and the sound isn't really memorable. The characters are even quite cliched, but they're funny and lovable nonetheless.


I wouldn't recommend this for being an awe-inspiring masterpiece, but I *would* recommend it because it was nothing but fun and hilarity, and it made me laugh more than any other anime or TV show I've watched. I fell in love with it five minutes into the first episode, and I absolutely adored every moment of it after.

I've completed the series some time back and absolutely LOVED IT. This is a 13 episode anime and I thought, "Eh, why not?". Turned out to be a very entertaining anime. The sidekick Alciel kinda reminds us of Hayato Gokudera from Katekyo hitman reborn (KHR). Overall a good comedy anime, brings a lot of laughs. What I thought is amusing is that one of the demon general that shows up later (Lucifer) went from "I WANT TO CONQUER EARTH" to settling in the apartment with Satan and Alciel after being defeated. If you're looking for a comedy and short anime, this is the one towatch.

Adios.

A disappointment. The premise sounds good, and like it could lend itself to a Swiftian satire of modern society, provide interesting contrasts between the poverty and inequity of the stock fantasy medieval setting and the world now, do fish-out-of-water and lowered-status gags, but instead, it's an inept package. The worldbuilding is nonexistent; the lead character *completely* implausible (there's *not even* a scene where he decides to become a hardworking peasant, much less a scrap of justification for abandoning world conquest for the joys of McDonald's) and adapts instantly & unamusingly to his new world ('gift of tongues', please), and the tsundere Hero is little better(he killed your family for no good reason, handing you an umbrella is not a reason to fall for him!); it indulges in the excuse of 'oops used up all my power repairing stuff' what, 3 or 4 times? which is 2 or 3 times more than it should've; the 'dialogue' is moronic (so, the final member of the harem is reproached for being an assassin for whom the end justifies the means just like for the demon? yes, yes, how very accurate - wait a second, when the deuce were we told the demons *had* any ends beyond bestial lust/greed/ambition?); and finally and worse of all: the comedy is bad. How many times is it funny to have Ashiya puke or talk about coupons, or have Lucifer order something online? Apparently 3 episodes' worth - except the series has 13 episodes.\n\n
If you just want the fantasy highschool romcom, stick to _Shakugan no Shana_. For fish-out-of-water, _Full Metal Panic! The Second Raid_ comes to mind as much funnier. For action... well, pretty much any series will do better. For world conquest by a misunderstood villain, _Maoyuu Maou Yuusha_sounds like it's at least thought-out. For economics, _Spice and Wolf_. For business lessons, _Moshidora_. _Hataraku Maou-sama!_ does nothing well.

Story: 9/10

From the first episode, i knew I'm watching something unique and i kept going watching it over the weeks (when it was airing), i stopped at episode 8 and left the anime for like a year.
Then the smart devil inside me told me to watch it again since i remembered how funny and easy going it is to watch.
What makes this anime easy going and fun to watch, is the amazing characters in it. It definitely made my day better than i expected!.
And don't forget how funny this anime is, i still remember some scenes that made me laughhard. Heck the first episode has a really funny scene when they landed at the human world and he tried to do magic with his hand then a wild Taxi stopped as if they called for him (that was really something i laughed at), if i mention every little funny thing happened i would probably finish this review as a novel. \n\n
They did an amazing job making the story in the best possible way you could ask for.\n\n
The story is the devil (Satan) escaped from Ente Isla, and fell into the human world where he can't use his full power then he just has to do what a normal human do, like get a job and stuff. Then hero Emilia followed him to the human world to deal with Satan. After that the story gets driven here in there, mostly funny as hell(sometimes epic).\n\n
Don't forget the amazing characters in this anime, just wow. They definitely made an amazing and loving characters, there is no way someone would hate a character in this anime (unless you want heaven, then you'd hate Sadao).\n\n
The art and the animation, it's nothing special to be honest, if it was really that overwhelming then i would say it deserves more than 8.\n
8 means really good, but it's not perfect.\n\n
Overall\n
I would love to write more about this anime but i think i reached my peak, sadly.\n
i just wanna clear that this anime is something i liked so much and deserves 9 in every aspect. It made my day and just watching it, remind me that you shouldn't take life seriously, and always have fun.

What is Hataraku Maou-sama?  Is it comedy?  Is it romance?  Is it a fantasy story?  Yes, but at it's core it is really something else.  In essence, it accomplishes perfectly what many anime fail at (at least to some degree).  It does its job as entertainment.  It is engrossing.  It is fun.  
It does work in a little romance, and a little humor, but it doesn't sit heavily over one genre line.  It is also refreshingly free of the ecchi content that so frequently sours other shows.
I'm not saying that "it's fun... caveat, caveat, caveat",like you might expect.  It is pure fun.  Where most shows fail, this one balances all its elements perfectly, with an elegance to this purity of fun that can have me saying only one thing:  Give me more!

I love this series.
That being said, it is not a perfect series. I gave this series high ratings all around, but it's based on pure opinion. 
The story is very different from pretty much everything I've watched and read. The problems most people have with the series is that the character's motives weren't clear or didn't seem natural for the story, and they might have felt it strayed too far from the original plot.
I can agree with that, but the difference is that I still enjoyed the story wherever it took me. I loved the characters and how they interacted with each other. For me,there was never a dull moment. \n
This isn't an anime that you need to turn your brain off to enjoy, like some other anime (cough cough Mirai Nikki cough cough). That being said, you do need to subdue the part of you that overanalyzes plot and characters and things like that. If you just watch the anime for what it is, a quirky story about a strange guy working at a rip-off of McDonalds, I'm sure you'll enjoy it, and I hope that you end up enjoying it as much as I did.\n\n
And also hope they make a second season. \n
Please.\n
Like seriously.\n
That was not a freaking ending.\n
I'll even just settle for an OVA.\n
Anything.

This anime isn't supposed to be taken very seriously. The characters were great but didn't have much of a story, which didn't mind me that much. The art was really good and matched the tone of the show, plus the music matched well too. Each character wasn't just bland or generic, and the English dub was amazing. It's incredible how they came up with this, the Devil working at a parody of McDonalds! It was creative and I did enjoy this show very much. It gives you a whole other point of view of the Devil, and it's fun to watch.

He was struck from his throne,

But love played her a fool,

Now sit down and pour a cold scotch,
We’re gonna kick it up onemore notch,\n
Because these birds of a feather,\n
Call even more queers together,\n
And god DAMN is it well worth the watch!

I've been down on my luck in my search for anime to watch after finishing Code Geass and Paranoia agent.  So i asked my followers on a Facebook page i admin for, they all said.  
"Watch this. It's really good." 
with that in mind i had to emphasize my guidelines for anime that i will watch.  I don't believe that i have high standards for anime to watch.  I want a show that has a good story and does a really swell job of influencing me to actually care for these characters.    
When i started, i was unsureof what i was watching because of the introduction; viewers are thrown into the middle of a war going on between king Satan and his rival 'the hero'  \n\n
Now when i was watching i had been absorbed into the comedic aspect of the dialogue between Satan and Hero emilia.  Almost completely forgetting the holy war that was going on.  I was disappointed to finish the show and NOT see a second season.  \n\n
In the end,  i would recommend this show to anyone looking for a Light hearted and funny show to watch.    \n\n
I would re watch at a later time.

Maou Sadao is a model employee at McRonalds. He is diligent, capable and SUPER keen and he is also the Lord of all things evil who gains power from suffering, Satan himself. It's a pretty fun premise and the anime plays out with a fun comedic vibe. Sadao finds himself living in modern Japan with his right hand man from another dimension, the slightly melodramatic Ashiya Shirou, who falls naturally into the role of frugal housewife and much hilarity ensues. Its a little bit of a shame that the women in the story aren't as interesting. There is the legendary hero living under the aliasYusa Emi who despite being some legendary hero of justice or something is just your typical needlessly confrontational tsundere who spends more time being embarrassed that everyone seems to think she is dating Sadao then she does doing anything particularly hero-like. No spoilers but her personality makes even less sense once her backstory gets developed. Then you have your typical cute junior at work complete with pigtails and G-cups who just desperately wants to make Sadao food all the time, Sasaki Chiho. She does archery too but only in the credits, it's never mentioned in the show which is kind of weird. They kind of complement the antics of the guys nicely but Emi (like most tsunderes) is quite annoying and I get the feeling Chiho is just there so they can make flat chest jokes about Emi. No, I am being unfair to Chiho, she is ok but just a teensy bit boring especially compared to the guys, her thing is pretty much being girly and in love with Maou. There are some other fun characters but I wont spoil them.


For those of you who are curious the art is quality. The first episode features some fight scene eye candy that made me wish it was actually an action anime. But even though it isn't so the rest of the show has a modern nice feel to it. It isn't particularly unique if that is what you are into but other than that it is pretty good. The character designs are fairly standard, as I mentioned before the women in general aren't particularly original; long red hair on the tsundere, orangy/brown pigtails on the cute junior and long dark hair on the emotionless girl in the traditional kimono. It's been done before but it looks quality so its ok. To be fair Maou's design also looks pretty standard for a comedy with harem tendencies.


I always put in a note about fan service because I personally don't really like it. This series starts out with not that much except an ending credit animation that is basically all fan service, but toward the end it gets a bit more. Mostly its in the form of the occasional boob joke, it didn't really bother me and if you aren't looking for it you wont really notice it. If you are looking for it you will get a few chances to see the girls in their underwear, even Maou gets some underwear scenes in this show. Anyways this show has something of a harem happening so naturally a few scenes where the girls forget to wear pants walking around the house is to be expected.


All in all its a pretty fun watch. It kind of fizzles something serious in the very last episode but the rest of it is entertaining and kept me watching all the way through. Its a fun way to spend some time, it won't rock your world or anything like that but it was fairly funny.

I was engaged in the story, intrigued by the world, in love with the characters and in awe of the action this is a series to be cherished. I first watched this show when I was just starting to get into anime so I still didn't have high expectations for this medium and then The Devil is a Part Timer was recommended to me. I watched the first episode and that was the first time an anime made me laughed, the first time I grew attached to the characters and wide eyed from the action, I loved every minute of my experience and was devastatedwhen it was over.


STORY-7

While watching this anime I was engaged in the story and eager to see the next revelation, but as I think back at it I can't really remember what the plot was really about. To be honest I don't think the story is really an important part of this series, it leads the characters into their new setting and allows them to adjust in the ways they see fit. The Devil is a Part Timer had a story that most will enjoy but it is nothing ground breaking, where this show really stands out is with the characters.


CHARACTERS-10

I love these characters because this show instead of painting these characters into their usual tropes it portrays them as normal everyday people with there own problems and responsibility (which is the cause of most of the humor), many of which we can all identify with. The devil is not the evil, menacing entity we would assume him to be, he's a man with bills and responsibilities, the hero isn't the big strong man that we should all base our decisions of of, she's a strong woman with her own personal grudges against the devil and who was pushed to take on the role of the hero. 


ENJOYMENT-10

This is simply one of the most enjoyable shows you will ever watch, you will laugh at the humor, get pumped from the action and love the character interactions this is a very fun show.

(First Review)
Hataraku Maō-sama! was loads of fun to say the least. The original concept of the story was well presented through the characters and comedy in the series. The art work was great and complimented the light-hearted style of this anime along with the sound. Overall Hataraku Maō-sama! was a comedy goldmine and a great short series to watch.

Have you ever wondered what happens to the characters after the finale of those animes whose end goal is to defeat a big bad demon lord? Now have you ever considered how the demon lord feels after being vanquished?
Hataraku Maou-sama! shows you a glimpse as to how those stories might continue. This anime cuts through the long cliche'd epic and bring you directly to the point where sequels will never be based on.
When the demon lord Sadao gets plunged into a world where there is no need for an ultimate evil, he does what every unemployed (and broke) villain might do: get a crappy dayjob and aspire to rebuild his now lost kingdom in the modern day.


Sure it has your light hearted comedy, slice of life fervor, and even over the top action scenes every now and then but what I really like about this anime is the chance to see what a villain would do given a chance to start over following their defeat.


Now I must admit this anime has its flaws (especially towards the last episode) but it was enjoyable to see such a story make its way into the scene. All I really hope is that it continues the way it started off and also continue adding dimension to a seemingly 2 dimensional role seen in most anime characters.


The rating I gave was really for what it could've or can become given a little more thought and heart. I recommend picking this anime up but I must warn viewers that you may ask for more and probably not get it anytime soon.

*Disclaimer: I watched the dub version, so the perception of comedic lines might differ if you watch subbed.
Story
While the story isn't revolutionary (bad guys cause trouble, good guy smacks them around) the setting is what truly shines through. The fusion of fantasy and modern day concepts sets the show up for some pretty funny situations. While I watched it for the laughs, I do have to say the story was satisfying enough but still leaving a possibility for a second season (which would be great).
Art
The whole show was visually appealing and battle scenes looked cool.
Sound
The sound affects in terms of background noise and battle soundswere good, but lets get to the real meat and potatoes.**Comments on the English dub** The two male leads were great in their roles having adequate emotions when they needed to. My biggest grip with the sound would probably be the female lead, who can be a bit annoying to listen to when she complains, but it was bearable.\n\n
Character\n\n
It made be an overused anime trope but I love the good guy (which is ironic) who is a hard worker. I also love the overpowered main character trope which sadly doesn't seem to do as well in Japan all of the time. (In terms of characters starting out overpowered) But Satan is a really like-able guy overall. The Hero starts of annoying, but she's fine overall, they just get her to butt heads with the MC to cause tension obviously. One of my favorite characters has to be King Satan's general Shiro. He is super loyal and often times funny, that pretty much sums him up.\n\n
Enjoyment\n\n
I have to say this is personally my favorite comedy anime. The banter between the characters can be hilarious and it's just overall a good time. The story is enjoyable enough, but the laughs combined with King Satan having his occasional kick butt moments are great.\n\n
Overall\n\n
This is just a very solid anime. If you want to relax, or want a good anime to binge watch, this is the one for you. I enjoyed my time with it significantly, and I hope you do too.

There is a tl dr at the end and to be honest that could have been the full review.
This show should have been called "Everyone but Chio is an asshole".
The story of Hataraku Maou Sama starts with a good premise but in a minute the lord Satan changes into a ecchi MC. A complete virgin with a good heart (maybe).
This could have been forgiven if his partner who is also a demon suffered this massive change of heart as well but he stays in character for the rest of the show (which is pretty much one of the only charming points of this anime sinceAshiya character is genuinely entertaining).\n\n
The Maou himself is so cliche that it kinda hurts and the whole "he is the lord of darkness" seems like a lazy explanation as to why so much bullshit happens around him instead of being actually true (probably there is a good explanation on the novels or manga but there wasnt one in the anime).\n
Also to add to the last point. This is so bullshit that the premise of the show could be considered fake.\n
The Hero is beyond stupid and annoying to the point i was genuinely happy when she was being tortured or being beaten the shit of.\n
Oh right there are a few action scenes and they were nice i guess.\n
Aside from Ashiya and Chio the rest of the cast is so damn forgettable, cliched, unoriginal or simply a complete waste of screen time (a little bit of drama was tried to be presented with the Inquisitor but the carefree nature of the show didnt allowed her story to be presented properly).\n
Aside from a few lines the comedy is nothing innovative. I was pretty much able to predict in which way the shots were being made so nothing was too much of a surprise.\n
I mentioned early that the show is carefree so no drama can be properly presented but this works on the opposite way (i know it makes no sense but what the hell), the show is so serious that the comedy is too limited and the jokes are really weak.\n
Also something really serious happens on ep 9 or so but the Maou or any other of the characters that were present at that time says anything about it so you just end up wondering if that was just a crazy allucination that you had, to cope with the massive ammount of "meh" that this show is.\n
The only reason i didnt dropped this by the 6º episode was because i wanted to see more of Chio.\n
I tried really hard to enjoy this show and i'm actually going to read the manga because i know i predicted everything right (and also im a complete masochist). I know exactly what the Maou, the hero and where the plot is going to go, but i wanna be wrong.\n\n
tl dr: The story is so cliched and unoriginal that you could fall asleep, 90% of the characters are annoying or boring, the sound and art are nothing spectacular.\n

actually most enjoyable anime that ive ever watched. im glad someone recommend me this series. if ure going to watch anime that very easy to come i mean u dont need to be serious keeping ur eyes on the monitor to see the plots.   
joyful cheers that the words describe this show. very funny show tho i hope they can make the season 2 xD  (fk actually impossible).
beside that theres thing that i was curious in the story. nevermind its a joke yeah its comedy show that brings alot of joyfull and cheers. 
And one more : yusa emi is bae :0. bae bae bae (its not spoiler)\n\n
Hope u enjoy the show

A Christian's Anime Review
The Devil Is a Part Timer
Discernment Topics
Violence: \/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/
The first episode shows sweeping battle scenes with scores of dead.
Magic is used to destroy cityscape and punch bloodless holes through people.
Melee weapons are used in battle occasionally.
Magic torture accompanied by cries of pain are featured in one episode.
Slapstick violence occurs frequently.
Language:\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/
Mild language. Moderate language occasionally crops up.
Spiritual Content:\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/
As the title implies, the main character is known as "The Devil". He does not, however, resemble the Devil of Christianity in any way but name. Instead, the Devil is shown as a deposed ruler of a foreign dimension who strives to do all he can tobe the best at his part-time job.\n
A pseudo-Catholic church organization exists in another dimension. It is shown to be hypocritical, and self-serving. One priest from it's organization plays the part of a villain.\n
An angel who claims to be acting on the part of "heaven" commits villainous acts and is clearly a pervert.\n
A character named "Lucifer" is said to have once lived in heaven, but is now a demon.\n
One character is said to be half-angel. Other characters are said to be of a race of demons.\n\n
Fanservice:\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\n
Semiperpetual fanservice in the form of character design.\n
Occasional overt fanservice scenes.\n\n
Misc. Suggestive Content:\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\n
The titular "Devil" and his entourage put on an act of being evil near the beginning. They do hypnotize some policemen and government officials to secure some identity cards, but don't really do anything else "evil" the rest of the time.\n
In fact, the "Devil" is downright heroic in many parts. Some people may find this theme to be uncomfortable.\n\n\n
Detached Assessment\n\n
Story:\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\n
8/10\n
Fantasy comedy with aspects of romance and slice of life.\n
Interesting setting. Somewhat of a reverse Isekai.\n
Development of plot remains engaging throughout.\n
Comedy carries a lot of the episodes, and quite admirably at that.\n
Some minor plot holes. Maybe these were better explained in the original material.\n
Not a lot of conclusion. This is expected from an incomplete adaption though.\n\n
Characters:\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\n
9/10\n
Characters were well done and very entertaining to watch interact with one another.\n
The devil, however, seemed too much like a teenager to be someone who once ruled a vast kingdom and fought extensive wars. Actually, this is a trait with other demons as well. Perhaps there is some explanation for their shift in behavior from evil overlords to sloppy teenagers, but I didn't see any.\n\n
Art:\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\n
8/10\n
Art was good. It served it's purpose.\n
Character designs were well done.\n
Magic fights had some special effects that were kinda strange though.\n\n
Sound:\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\n
8/10\n
OP and ED are both good. Nothing remarkable though.\n
OST is similar. It serves it's purpose, but doesn't stand out.\n\n
Enjoyment:\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\n
9/10\n
Comedy was very good. Had a great time laughing.\n
Pacing kept me interested.\n\n
Conclusion\n
All things considered, this was a very worthwhile comedy show.\n
The fanservice was a bit off-putting, especially in one episode.\n
If you want something really funny and kind of sweet, this show is a good pick.\n
Additionally, I hear the original material, the light novels, are pretty good as well. Some people might jump into those after enjoying this.

A funny, charming slice-of-life about a demon working at McDonald's.
★★★★
It’s really hard to be funny. It’s even harder when you’re translating it across cultures. Humor is weighed down by where you’re from. To really appreciate a joke you need to have grown up with TV, pop culture, and socialize with the people around you. A joke referencing the stagnant Japanese economy just isn’t the same. That’s a why a punch in the groan is funny here and funny in China. It’s easy, it’s visual, and everyone can relate. Who hasn’t had their genitals harmed?
The fundamental, molecular parts of a joke are the setup and punchline.You create expectations, and you surprise your audience. The Devil Is A Part-Timer doesn’t rely on references or your cultural baggage to be funny. But the show doesn’t try hard to be funny. It’s the natural tone of it. It’s a slice of life.


So you’ve got this Devil king who escapes into the real world. He loses his powers and needs to find a way home. He starts at the bottom of society and gets a part time at a “McRonald’s.” It’s not called “McDonald’s”, but, let’s be honest, it’s fucking McDonald’s.


Do you remember that kid in your class—yeah, the fat one?—they were the class clown and everyone thought they were funny? It’s because when you expect someone to be funny they come off that way. Or you really like someone and you’ll just laugh at whatever shitty joke they tell just to get into their pants?


I found the cast of characters to be immensely charming. They had chemistry and plenty of friction to keep things exciting. There’s the loyal sidekick, a girl the main character fights with, another girl he fights with, and someone trying to kill him but ends up being roommates with. Did I mention he becomes a shift leader at his job, too?


There’s not much to complain about. It ends suddenly because it’s an adaption so enjoy it for what it is. It’s a fish-out-water story.

This show is probably one of my favorite Anime Series of all time. Everything about this show is great, it has a very developed and vibrant story, it has stunning and very colorful art work, the music and sound is awesome the characters are fun and likable and this show is very enjoyable.
Story: Defiantly a 10/10. The story progresses very fluently and there aren't many holes or disturbances in the story and plot, for example the development of Maou working at MgRonalds is very fluent and smooth.
Art: 10/10. Since this show was from FUNimation I was expecting top notch art and visuals, and FUNimation didn'tdisappoint. The art was very colorful, vibrant and appealing to the eye.


Sound: 10/10. The sound in this show is very good. The theme song is nice and catchy the in show music is also very nice to listen to. Even the voices on the characters match their personalities and appearances well. Frankly, the English dub had the best voices on the characters especially Chi's voice in the dub. 


Character: 10/10. I LOVE THE CHARACTERS. Every character is likable and has their own charm. My personal favorite character was probably either Maou or Emi. Most of the humor came from Emi and Maou is really cool and likable (when he isn't the devil king)


I really enjoyed this show but there was only one thing wrong with this show, The Ending. I thought the ending just came out of no where and that it just left the viewer dumbstruck. I really encourage FUNimation to continue with this show because this is a great show. Overall this show gets a 10/10 and I would highly recommend this show!

(This has been adapted from my reddit thread)
For many people, it is always difficult to go to a foreign land. Different languages, money, locales, and people make going to new places both exciting and daunting. Thus the stage is set for the Overlord in The Devil is a Part-Timer.
STORY
Our story begins in a completely fantastical land known as Ente Isla, where Dark Lord Satan and his demons wage war against Emilia the Hero and the Church. After these two titans of battle clash, Satan flees through the Gate, only to arrive in modern day Japan. Emilia, whose only purpose in fighting is to defeat theOverlord, gives chase.


What follows afterwards is actually a slice-of-life anime where our two protagonists and their compatriots learn to deal with the troubles of their new world. Namely, being human and having to work to earn money. This all seems rather simple. And to be honest, it is. But it works (pun intended).


One of the things I liked most about the story was how human it all seemed. Emilia herself is human, but watching her and especially Maou (the name he gives himself) having to deal with getting food, worrying about their finances, or helping out a local park were interesting mainly because their actions on Earth were in the completely opposite direction to what they were doing in Ente Isla. And this is true for the rest of the cast, such as Ashiya maintaining his complete devotion to Satan while keeping a strict eye over what was cheap enough to eat.


The show also incorporates the mythical side of their characters and the lore even though they live in Japan. Many of the arcs that the characters go through are ultimately related to the happenings in the world in which they originally called home. These parts as well were fine.


One of the main reasons why I picked this up was for the romance element. I will say that there are splashes of romance here and there (and it is pretty obvious that Emilia is tsundere early on) but I wish there was more romance to be had.


ANIMATION


When looking at another thread, I agree that the first episode had very good production quality. This was mainly because it makes the show out to seem as if what is going to be occurring is an action anime. So many of the fight scenes and designs/environments are nicely animated.


For the remainder of the show, the animation itself is passable, but nothing great or even good. It is average at best. This is mainly because most of what the characters do on-screen throughout the show is more commonplace activities, but there are moments when the animation does increase in quality (again, this is during the action sequences).


I actually liked the character designs. I think what I liked most about them were the use of color. Emilia's hair is a somewhat dark-red (as opposed to someone like Rias Gremory with her bright red hair), Lucifer is a calm purple, etc. This may also sound weird, but what I liked most about the character designs were their eyes. The animators went with more dull looking colors and no extra details. With Maou's orange eyes, Emilias dull green (I really liked her's), and Suzuno's baby blue eyes, they seemed kind of unique to me in a strange way.


CHARACTERS


This is easily the strongest part of the show. I think the best way to describe them would be "smart". That is, there really aren't many misunderstandings that take place and even when they do they are resolved rather quickly. Their "smart" behavior also comes from how they talk with one another. I think with the exception of Chiho, all of the main cast are 18 years old or older, meaning everything they say or do is more adult oriented. And this was refreshing when many anime tend to take place within the high school/pre-adulthood setting.


The two strongest characters are obviously, in this case, the two protagonists, Maou and Emilia.


Maou is probably one of my favorite MCs. He is kind, intelligent, and hard-working. On top of that, he can be a badass when he needs to. And for an MC in a potential harem he isn't even that dense (except for the gag with Chiho). It's sort of difficult to describe really. I think a lot of it has to do with the dichotomy between his human persona (really good guy) versus his devil persona (really bad guy). His evil side is especially cool because when he enters that state he is extremely overpowered, and rightly so (he is the king of the devils after all).


Emilia is also very fun to watch. I enjoy a good tsundere character, and she fits the bill nicely. She reminds me of a more angry and older Asuna of SAO fame. I enjoyed watching her interact with Maou and the other characters. She acts like a big sister to Chiho, she gets easily annoyed with Lucifer, and she has these rather complicated feelings towards Maou. Overall, she was definitely a joy to have on-screen.


As for the other characters, I liked them too. Ashiya, Lucifer, Chiho, and Suzuno all have their moments, and their personalities are fun and interesting.


The only gripe I have is that besides their base personality traits, there is no actual character growth. I would have liked to see more development within the first season in regards to Maou, Emilia, and the rest, but I guess that will just have to wait for season two.


SOUND


The OP for the show was not that good, but the ED grew on me. It's good but not amazing. The rest of the soundtrack is nothing special.


The voice acting for the show was nicely done by each of the cast members. There were no stand out performances, but I thought the actors/actresses did a very nice job.


ENJOYMENT


When it comes to most shows, I like them a lot. Perhaps it is just me being more open to everything, but I guess that's just the way I am. This is especially true when romance is mixed in, even if it is small. For Hataraku, there isn't technically a small amount of romance but it is also not the main focus. However, I still enjoyed the romance elements.


The show is also quite funny. This is mainly due to how well the cast interacts with one another. Chiho is also one of the funnier characters in the show due to how she over-reacts to most situations. Maou and Emilia are also great on-screen together, and I was always smiling when they were. On top of that, the writing is also nicely done. Much of the comedy comes from how serious Maou, Ashiya, and Emilia can be about the simple things in their new life, but it is all very nicely done.


One of the most enjoyable parts of the show is when Maou is able to fight properly. When watching it, you can definitely tell how strong and intimidating he becomes. This scene in particular (spoilers, don't watch otherwise) demonstrates well how scary he can be when he goes all out.


SUMMARY


Story: Fine, Dark Lord and the Hero deal with everyday life


Animation: Fine, nice character designs with adequate fight scenes


Characters: Good, cast works very well together but lacks character development


Sound: Fine, good voice acting and a good ED


Enjoyment: Great, some romance, pretty funny, and good writing


Final Score: 6/10

(This review is 98% SPOILER FREE. The 2% is negligible. Also,  for a quick summary, refer to the FINAL THOUGHTS section)
A demon lord working at MgRonalds!!
What pops up in your mind? (i.e:Apart from Ronald reagan..)
Hilarious situational comedy? Eccentric characters?
Well, that is what you expect when starting this show and for the most parts that is what you get.
Story:
The main core of the story as well as it's direction is quite predictable once you've read the synopsis. 
5 minutes into the first episode and you can already see where it is going but that is not a bad thing at all.
An all-conquering, all-powerful demon lordhas been forced to flee from his world called Ente Isla to modern day Japan along with his demon general. 

But, (and it's a big but necessary 'but') they have lost most of their powers and so are left to fend for themselves which leads us to the main point in the story where the demon lord (now with the adopted name of Maou Sadao) is forced to work at the local outlet of MgRonalds to earn a living for the two of them.

Being from a foreign world, it is easy to see that they are gonna have problems settling down in this newfound environment. But, slowly but surely they are able to do so. Add in the female  'hero' who defeated the demon lord in Ente Isla + a human girl in love with the now quite humanly demon lord + other characters from the other world and what we get is lots of laughs.

What I most liked about this setting was that it didn't involve the word 'school'! That was a bit refreshing to me after watching lots of high-school based SoLs and romcoms. This setting was made for the comedy aspect and does very well for the series. The characters' attempts at making ends meet and adapt produces lots of laughs.

The only problem I had with the plot was that the 'demon-lord' along with his army supposedly committed lots of heinous crimes on their attempt at conquering the world. However, in the modern-day-Japan setting where most of the story takes place, I started to feel that that dark-history was a bit misplaced for this comedic and light show. 


Characters:

The characters are not that unique. Or a better statement would be that they are how you'd guess them to be. But that doesn't stop the viewer from loving them.


Maou Sadao: The main protagonist Maou Sadao/Demon Lord is a little bit more eccentric and rash than the average male protagonist. He has a fair amount of leadership qualities, is thankfully not dumb and not (too) dense. But of course, he is kind and such.  His main objective has shifted to 'world domination' by climbing the coorporate ladder at MgRonalds. He starts to become more and more attached to this new-found world of burgers and fries and it slowly becomes clear that he doesn't intend to try to go back to his world any time soon. 

He is especially cool when he gets back his powers and demonic form through people's negative emotions. In that form, his power knows no bounds!!


Ashiya Shirou: The devoted and loyal demon general of the demon lord who is now in more of a 'housewife' role. A constant source of LOLs is his attempt at trying to help Maou in any way he can including making sure they don't spend more than they can afford!! An enjoyable character.


Yusa Emi: The 'hero' is your typical tsunderish girl. She followed Maou and Ashiya into Japan and is now working at a call centre. She is independent, rather capricious and is not so keen on holding back her fists and sword. She has a tragic past caused mostly due to the demon lord and his minions. So, it is hard for her to accept the fact that Maou is now a harmless (i.e in his long term plans) bum who finds delight in becoming the shift manager at a fast food outlet. Her dilemma at how to come to terms with this sudden transformation in the demon lord is shown in the right amounts: just enough to make us remember/acknowledge the events of Ente Isla but not overly present so as to add too much unnecessary drama.


Sasaki Chiho: A high-schooler who has fallen head over heels for the demon lord. Forbidden love?? Don't know. But fortunately for us: unforbidden hilarity. Her attempts at making Maou realize her feelings and her subsequent reactions/expressions when they fail are to die for. 


The other characters are mostly from Ente Isla. They include Angels, demons and priests along with the humans of course. What is interesting to see is how each of them adopt a different lifestyle and slowly but surely blend into the Japanese community along with the main set of characters. 


Art:

The art was pretty decent. Nothing unusual about it. What did strike the right cord are all the varied facial expressions. I thought they were really well done ( a possible treasure trove for memes and trolls). The fight scenes were also animated well along with the transformations of the characters from their human forms to the supernatural forms. So, basically average in this department.


Sound:

The voice acting was also average. No annoyingly voiced characters as far as I'm concerned. 

The sound tracks were not worth remembering. 

Although at first I found the opening 'Zero' to be better, as the series went on I started to prefer the endings by nano.RIPE .


------------------------------------------------------------------


FINAL THOUGHTS


Cons:

-The plot is not engaging enough. Although in all sincerity, it is probably not meant to be.

-The dark story from Ente-Isla and the light-hearted comedic one that unfolds in Tokyo seem to belong to different shows altogether.


Pros:

++The comedy. The LOLs. 

+the out-of-the-norm setting

+Interesting transformations: Demon Lord-> Part-timer , Former angel/demon general -> a NEET!! 

+slight romance but no forced dramas.


Scores:

Entertainment: 8.5

Everything-else: 6


Overall: 7.25 = 7


Recommended for those searching for a series with lots of laughs, light hearted theme and no mind-benders.

Enjoyable.


Side-note: A second season would be nice. Something with the same amount of comedy, a bit more romance and tying up of the unresolved plot. The LN is ongoing, so hoping for it.


------------------------------------------------------------------

(Feedbacks and comments (both +ve and -ve) would be highly appreciated.)

(This review may contain spoilers as I am writing whatever comes into mind)
I was really excited for this anime when I saw the preview and I was so happy when the first episode was released. It is a fantasy,comedy and a maybe a little bit of romance anime. 
Story : 9/10
The story shows about a world where humans and demons are at war in a world called Ente Isla. And of course there would be the dark lord and the hero. However the dark lord was defeated by the hero and was forced to retreat to another world which is modern day Tokyo, and itshows how the dark lord which is registered as a citizen of Japan named Maou Sadao and the hero Emi Yusa. The story was definitely very interesting as it shows how the hero and the dark lord both try to survive the financial trouble of their everyday life. Overall its rare to see this kind of story but they managed to pull it off really well.


Art : 10/10
