The English voices are perfect for the characters but again, since it’s made by Funimation, there is Funimation’s voice acting all over it. I just give them props for not going with a lot of names that have been said way to many times. Josh Grelle and Felecia Angelle, Tia Ballard and Anthony Bowling… These are names that I haven’t heard very often in the main character list. I might be wrong to say this and people can correct me but normally I hear Monica Rial, Caitlin Glass, or even Vic as main voices. I was surprised to not hear Vic’s voice for Satan and though I do love Vic, it was refreshing.


I really liked this show even if it was similar to many other shows, and I wouldn’t mind watching it again. If your looking for new and exciting, this isn’t the one, if your looking for one that plays it safe, this might be your show. Now if only they would come out with season two so I can get a actual ending like the manga, that would really be nice.

I just finished all 13 episodes and I have to say, I was very impressed with this show. I think most people assumed this show was going to be another bland and unfunny anime, and I think we were all taken by surprise after the first episode. The best part? The show stays just as good and funny throughout most of the season. 
This show is funny. Like really funny. This was easily the best comedy this season, and I'll bet it'll end up as the funniest anime this year. There really isn't anything to say about the comedy in this show, besides that itwas more clever than I had thought, and that it wasn't just spouting off random jokes 24/7 just to get a good laugh 1 or 2 times. That, along with the fact that the jokes in the show were more "universal" is what puts this show above most comedies like it. Shows like Gintama and Lucky Star can be funny, but only if you are an otaku. This show manages to be funny without every joke feeling like an inside joke and possibly going over your head. In that regard, it felt more like a sitcom (well, one with an actual plot)instead of your usual comedy anime. But probably the most surprising thing about the show was how good the story was. 


The story on its own won't be winning any awards or anything, but for a comedy anime I was pleasantly surprised with how good the story was. The best part and probably the icing on the cake for why I liked this show so much is because it made me laugh, had a good story, but didn't get overly dramatic like many comedies tend to do and it didn't go overboard with the romance. It is a rare gem indeed to find a show that doesn't fall into that, which is why I like this show so much.


 But it isn't all gumdrops and ice cream for this show.If I had to point out its flaws, I'd say that the story could get a little side tracked at times, and some episodes just weren't as funny as others. There was an episode or 2 between the two arcs, which weren't as good as the rest of the show, and there was a generic beach episode that wasn't very good either (the beach episode was funny though). I also find it weird that the show never mentions why the Satan himself became such a good person. Honestly, after watching the show I completely forgot he was evil. I suppose it's because he is smart, and acting evil at his job would cause him to get fired, but it doesn't explain all his actions in the show. It isn't the most consistent comedy you'll ever see, but it is one of the few that could make you laugh dozens of times an episode while still having an interesting plot. I should also point out that it had a good ending, and since the last "arc" ended the previous episode, nothing felt rushed or anything and it felt like a normal day.


As for the characters, I liked them all, so I don't have any complaints here. Most of the cast didn't get any real development or anything, but I think it is better off like that otherwise it could have gotten too serious for my liking. Besides, these characters will make you laugh every episode, do you really need to know their life story? Admittedly some characters were better than others (Alciel was the funniest character IMO), but they all have their moments and none of them hinder the show in any way. 


The production values on this show were also good, but nothing out of his world. The score in the show was pretty good, and I liked how it sounded very exotic at times (it felt like music you would hear on Ente Isla). The animation was very smooth, so I have no complaints there either. I would like to mention the faces the characters make throughout the show, as they are some of the funniest expressions I have seen in an anime. Honestly I haven't seen expressions that funny since GTO. 


Overall, I liked this show a lot, as it was one of the more clever comedies I have seen (hell at times it was even too clever for me). But what really makes it stand out is how it doesn't fall into the traps that other comedy anime tend to fall into like melodrama and cheesy romance. It's a show that stayed true to it's roots, and thats why I'm giving it such a good score. It deserved it. 


Final Verdict (86/100) - Watch it if you want something very funny, that doesn't go overboard with the drama and romance. It's also a good start for someone who hasn't watched much anime and wouldn't get the otaku jokes in other comedy series.

In a distant fantasy world far far away, a malevolent demon Overlord is about to conquer all of humanity. His armies butcher humans and burn the countryside, sparing no one and spreading fear and horror across the land. Humanity's last hope comes in the form of a Hero of no equal, raised in virtual secrecy. After countless struggles the righteous human armies, led by said Hero, push back at the demon armies and eventually corner the Overlord in his own castle, forcing him to flee the battle along with his chief strategist. The Overlord gives a foreboding warning that they will return before jumping througha portal to... modern day Japan. There, the former villains find themselves faced with even greater challenges- chariots that move by themselves, a culture filled with abstruse rules, mana that can no longer be replenished, and endless burgers to cook and serve. Just as the pair seems to have established a small beachhead in this foreign land, they find that they are not alone. Others from Ente Isla have followed in their wake, and among them is the very Hero that drove them out.


Maou Sama is a hilarious twist to the fantasy world portal genre. This somewhat action-oriented show is like a cross between the cultural humor in Outbreak Company, the too-lazy-to-be-a-hero fantasy elements from Yusibu, and some plot elements and protagonist traits from Blood Lad. The story is very straightforward and falls into the tasteful shonen category, and surprising stays mostly out of harem territory. If you're looking for a solid watch with a bit of fantasy and magic, this is a pretty good one- for veterans and newcomers alike.


Animation:

The animation quality is pretty good overall. The show has a fairly saturated color palette with softly drawn lines and fair backgrounds. The overall treatment is a bit uneven as certain scenes have great lighting and detail while others appear more plain. You get a good mix of flashback scenes in Ente Isla so I'd say the setting is 2/3 mega city and 1/3 fantasy land. Character designs are pretty decent, starting with the hilarious demon capes that the Japanese police immediately dismiss as cosplay. They do a good job at some of the finer details as well, the former Overlord and our protagonist Maou Sadao has demonic red eyes and snake-like pupils, which surprisingly don't look all that menacing when attached to a dude in a burger joint uniform. Hilariously, the buff, miasma-emitting bodies of the demons are reduced to those of ordinary humans when stripped of their mysterious mana source, thus our protagonist (aside from his eyes) ends up looking like any other harem male lead.


There are a fair number of fights as well as accidents (most of them involving slippery stairs). While not choreographed to the level of a full on action thriller, expect some nice effects and decent intensity (and massive collateral damage). This series surprisingly didn't go the harem route so don't expect too much ecchi aside from the now mandatory comparison between girls' bust sizes and swimsuit episode.


Sound:

The show starts with a fitting light-action OP that reminds me a bit of Infinite Stratos. The melody isn't that great but it works nonetheless. The main ED is much slower and has a chorus that brings up vibes from Sankarea's ED; this is probably one of Nano Ripe's less annoying songs. The BGM is passable but nothing special and likewise for sound effects.


The VA cast is pretty experienced with both heroine VAs doing a pretty good job in their respective roles. I also found Ente Isla's language particularly humorous, and there are surprisingly a lot of tongue-twisted lines in that fantasy language (though conveniently enough the Hero's flashbacks are in Japanese). The antagonists are a bit too obviously voiced though; you practically can guess deceit just from the voice. Overall a pretty run of the mill sound effort.


Story:

This is where I was a bit surprised, pleasantly. Maou, for whatever reason, decides that this new world called Earth is pretty interesting and sets his ambitions to conquer it along with Ente Isla. However, in an un-demonic fashion he decides to do so playing by the rules of the land, by working his way up the corporate ladder of a Mc Donald's clone chain. Thus, the most feared being in one world is turned into the employee of the month at your local fast food stop. The degradation in stature doesn't end there, as we soon find that the Hero is likewise reduced to working at a call center. It was quite unique seeing the two clash while trying to maintain their professional lives and barely scrounge by with an impoverished lifestyle.


The show follows a central plot line with occasional introductions of new characters and antagonists. The actual battles and events are fairly predictable (it is shonen after all) but still enjoyable nonetheless. The story grows to an eventual climax, which actually feels unnaturally forced in my opinion, and finishes with a touching deja vu of an earlier sequence in the show. It's fairly open ended but still satisfying enough. Best of all, the show does a pretty good job of tidying up corners, explaining most of the would-be plot questions.


Character:

Maou may resemble your typical harem lead, but he acts nothing like it. He's a surprisingly reliable and hard-working individual who puts the success of his workplace and coworkers before himself. Likewise, the Hero, is not what you expect either. She is clumsy, quick to anger, and surprisingly spiteful. Thus, the show does a good job of separating the protagonists from the usual stereotypes. There is also comic and playfully romantic relief in the form of Chiho, Maou's coworker. There is a decent amount of development with all the above characters but viewers hoping for a Maou-Yuusha route will be stymied (sadly).


However, the other supporting characters are more of your standard fare business. In particular, I don't think Lucifer and Suzuno were developed to their full potential, especially considering how prominent their roles were at various plot points. And Olba... there's no way you could get a more stereotypical antagonist.


Value:

Though the show comes across as predictable, it is a solid work for its genre nonetheless and a very easy watch. It doesn't have much in rewatch value due to its simplicity but it is thoroughly enjoyable for both plot involvement and character interactions. If you're looking for a relatively light action/comedy, this is a good choice. Grab a seat and maybe a burger and enjoy!

"Heaven is a place on Earth. It exist in a certain six tatami mat, second floor mat. Being a bum is the best." -Hanzou Urushihara
"...Being a bum is the best.", that quote left me speechless, as I was laughing on the floor endlessly for 10 minutes. If you're looking for an anime to binge-watch on for the whole weekend, this is an anime for you! This anime had witty humor, odd characters, bizarre scenarios, and the main character being a total dunce(in a good way). For myself, I personally enjoyed this anime, there was never a moment in the series that I was thought, "Damn,this is boring!" Instead, my mind was like, "Oh my god! Oh my god! Oh my god! What's going to happen next!?" Like my mind was tripping on acid you know? Just kidding. Every moment was enjoyable as I laughed every two seconds every time the characters had to say something. Every episode makes you want to watch the next and the next and the next...until you have no more left.\n\n
This is great show to watch on a weekend, if you're looking for an anime that'll make your stomach hurt days without end. I definitely enjoyed watching this anime and recommend to everyone!

Do you ever wonder what it'd be like if a dark lord or SATAN HIMSELF came into our world and worked part-time at a fast food restaurant that totally isn't based off McDonalds? Well this anime shows what it''d be like. Hataraku Maou-sama (The Devil is a Part-timer in English) is a spring 2013 anime and if you like slice of life, comedy anime then this anime is for you. Anyway, let's get into the review.
Story: 6/10
This anime is a slice of life anime, so there isn't really much of a story to it. However, there is some kind of story as in it givesa bit of detail about the devil, what he does and where he lives. However, while it does talk about the stuff that happens in the world the devil and the other characters (except Chiho, who lives on Earth) live in, I feel that it doesn't go into depth enough. It was certainly interesting, but i feel that it could've given more of a background story of the characters and their lives in the crazy world they live in. While does give a bit of a background story about Emilia "The Hero) when it shows her as a child, her being recruited and then her village being burnt down by the devil's army, I would've liked to see more of what it was like for her growing up. Did she find training hard at first? Did she ever lose any battles she regrets losing? You know, that kind of stuff. 


The same goes for the other characters too, we're given no information about their lives in this crazy world. While i did enjoy watching it and I know it's just a slice of life anime, in this situation it would've been nice to give a good backstory for all the characters. Heck, maybe even tell us more about Chiho. I'm interested in the Church, who in a way are made out to be the bad guys and crazy. I'm also interested in the different islands and the people on them. Do they get along? Is there any tension? Maybe I'm looking too much into this but when it's a fantasy world similar to those of KonoSuba or Re:Zero, then I want to see a good backstory explaining things. i want to get to know the characters more. I did enjoy what the anime gave us though, I just feel it could've been added to.


Art 7/10

This anime was animated by the studio called White Fox, who have also animated Re:Zero. While I do like Re:Zero's animation better and I've seen shows animated better that this one, I still think the animation was good, especially in some bits where it's really good, such as Chiho's jealousy causing her to get angry at Satan. The characters are cute (particularly Chiho) and look nice. Everything else is done nicely too. It's just nice, simple animation and I'm happy with what I saw. Not amazing but certainly not bad.


Sound 8/10

I found this anime very pleasant to listen to, whether that be the background music, the opening and ending or just general things like the characters talking. Non of them had some overly "cute", squeaky voice (looking at you English dubs for anime!) and the opening and ending songs, while forgettable, were good, although they're not something I'd listen to over and over again like the opening and endings for New Game or Nichijou. The background music was pretty good and nice to listen to.


Character 9/10

Like i said before, the characters were cute and I found them all hilarious. Each character has their own backstory and is unique in a way, although like i said before, i feel their backstory wasn't explored enough. They were still interesting and funny characters though. Some people might say Chiho was just fan service because of her large boobs but I disagree. Yes, she has large boobs and she's cute but there's more to her than that. She was still an important part of the show. It's a slice of life anime though, so fan service is acceptable as long as the character still has good things about them and reasons to like them other than "they're sexy", like Rem from Re:Zero or Mikasa from Attack on Titan. Like I mentioned before, the characters are all unique, funny and likeable. It's a shame that this show doesn't have a 2nd season and that not much of a backstory was given for these undoubtedly interesting characters.


Enjoyment 10/10

I enjoyed this anime very much and there weren't any moments were I started feeling bored or annoyed. It made me laugh every episode (especially the funny language that is spoken in Satan's world) and I'd definitely watch a season 2. It's a nice slice of life, comedy anime and I got what I expected.


Overall 8/10

I give this anime an 8/10 rating. While it does have some flaws, they are minor and luckily did not effect the humour or quality of this very good anime. Like I said before, I enjoyed it very much and I think you'll probably enjoy it too if you like slice of life, comedy anime. If you're new to this genre or even new to anime, then I don't think this anime is a bad place to start.

Story
When it comes down to it, The Devil is a Part Timer manages to present some good ideas and scenarios, but is so caught up in its fictional world of Ente Isla that it falls apart and becomes less of the slice-of-life/comedy it should have been and more of an uninteresting action show. In fact, by the end it almost feels like it’s become a harem anime. The Devil is a Part Timer doesn’t know what it wants to be and suffers because of it.
The plot starts in Ente Isla where the Dark Lord Satan and his army is ravaging the lands and mercilessly killingpeople. There is a church and an inquisition and God and all kinds of other fun religious stuff, though none of it is fleshed out much because before you can get a feel for this fantasy world, you’re in Tokyo where Satan—calling himself Maou—has become an employee at a McDonalds. These slice-of-life portions in which Satan is acting like a normal human are entertaining and rife with good comedic moments. The romance between a high school girl working at the McDonalds and Satan is a good thread for the series to run with, which you’d hope would develop characters and push the story, but the romance, sadly, is put on the backburner.


Instead the series focuses more on various characters from Ente Isla coming to Tokyo to cause problems. This should have been expected from the beginning, but there is no build-up to this happening. By the time Lucifer shows up, you’re expecting the series to be centered on Satan, his loyal servant Ashiya, and Emi the Hero. The series falls apart at this point and never truly recovers. It goes back to slice-of-life, goes to action portions, cuts back to Ente Isla for some reason. It’s such a mish-mash that it’s hard to find one aspect truly enjoyable.


One thing the series does do right and I could pick out of the mess of ideas was the comedy. The series remained pretty funny throughout, though much of the comedy came from one specific character. And I guess the idea of angels and devils working for fast food chains is pretty hilarious.


There’s not enough going on in the story and writing to truly give the series much credit.


Animation

Good animation throughout with pretty good character models and richly detailed backgrounds. The fight scenes are pretty fluid as well.


Sound

The opening song is really catchy and all the other music certainly wasn’t bad either.


Characters

Despite the large cast, none truly stand out from their respective counterparts. Emi is a good tsundere character and I enjoyed her development as she slowly grows to like Maou. She still calls him her rival and treats him like garbage much of the time, but there’s steady development that I would love to see more of. The other romance, between Maou and Chiho, is cute, though one sided and ultimately not satisfying.


Ashiya is the only other character really worth mentioning because he’s the character who makes the series funny. His constant frugality and going home to get his cloak before appearing at a big battle is hilarious.


The other characters are forgettable and uninteresting.


Overall

The Devil is a Part Timer contains a lot of good ideas and scenarios but fails to create a cohesive bond between many of them and, because of that, fails to deliver anything solid. The comedy is worthwhile and a few of the characters are interesting, but everything else is flat, generic, and ultimately unmemorable. I can’t even write a real in-depth review because the show itself doesn’t have much depth. I enjoyed some of it, but the rest is easily forgotten.

I went into Hataraku Maou-Sama with some pretty low expectations, because in hindsight it’s the basic tried and done fish-out-of-the-water formula filled with clichés and try-hard humor. Instead, when I started, I was pleasantly surprised by colorful characters energetically bouncing off of each other, witty dialogue and fantastic comedic timing. At the same time Hataraku told a strong story that progressed quite well and perfectly kept its balance with the comedic aspects.
So it’s unfortunate for me to say that after episode five, Maou-Sama failed to hold up with its preceding episodes.
Not that it was downright awful, but episodes started ranging from really clever to reallynot-so clever. It lost its consistent quality and it lost a lot of its charm. Characters, while given strong characterization, were never given any real development and eventually became a mixed bag of like and dislike. Maou, Ashiya and Lucifer remained quite entertaining to watch, but Emi’s animosity and irrational anger grew old, Chiho’s infatuation with Maou grew annoying and Suzuno… well, she was quite generic and stale from the beginning.


The plot progression was thrown under the bus, and while the climax itself was incredibly well executed, the lead up itself was awful. The perfect balance between comedy and serious story telling was immediately tilted over to comedic side and it was almost as if the writers lost interest in trying to tell a genuine story. By the end, it was almost as if the writers forgot that the show needed a conclusion and so they just tossed in a climax.


No build up, no nothing and instead I had to endure some pretty bland filler episodes. Yeah, the McRonald/Sentucky rivalry was actually quite hilarious, but every other filler played out generically and it completely went against what made Maou-Sama a fun show in the first place.


There are two things I admire that Maou-Sama keeps consistent throughout the whole series. The first one is the fact that Maou-Sama actually makes use of its characters and setting its joke. Too many comedies fail simply because they don’t see the creative elements eagerly waving their arms right in front of their eyes. Instead they pull their jokes out of thin air and I appreciate that Maou-Sama avoids this mistake.


The second one is the fact that Maou-Sama always has a great sense of comedic timing, no matter how stupid the jokes, and I also applaud that.


So to summarize, the show starts and ends really, really well, but it’s plagued by a lackluster middle. Overall, I’d still have to say that I did enjoy the show. There were more high highs than low lows and if you can tolerate those low lows, then I would recommend this as a comedy.

Before I even talk about the specifics, I would like to say one thing. All of these are my own beliefs and I do not expect anyone to completely agree with them or agree with them at all. But as a person who have watched almost all genre of anime, and countless number of shows (I do not really feel like adding all to my profile), I believe my opinion may help someone who has trouble deciding Hataraku Maou-snama! is worth their time or not. 
Story:
The show does not try to stay comical or try to stay serious the whole time.It tries to maintain thebalance of comedy and drama but it doesn't work out. By not focusing on either one, it dilutes the drama and the comedy when it happens. Because of this factor, it was not able to create a solid story line, but gave general ideas each time something happened. In the end, the story line was not satisfactory, and the viewers are left with feeling as if something is missing. But this does NOT necessarily mean that the show is bad. There are other shows that doesn't have an overarching story that ends up good. Even though the end product was dis satisfactory, I do not believe the producers went for a show too serious, which makes the lack of story a little understandable. 


Character:

Characters are absolutely confusing at times.


(There will be some spoilers for this part. But the most if not all of them are revealed in the first two or three episodes.)


There are quite a few main characters that just blows my mind. The Overlord, a.k.a. Satan, is projected as the evil being that slaughtered and destroyed anything that lay before him if it got in his way. Well he is for the first one minute anyways. As soon as he enters the human realm, he becomes the ultimate good guy. THERE IS NO LOGIC. Even his ruthless right wing general turns into a good guy. The show tries to pin this on the fact that they have lost their powers, but i'll go out on a limb and say SATAN, who was responsible for the death of millions, will just bow down and serve the humans he despised. Not only serving them, but going out of his way to save them. The show does occasionally reminds the viewers that he is Satan, but it doesn't matter because he is still acting like the HERO of the show. But lets say I can accept the fact that Satan turned into a good guy. How about the fact that servants of Gods (Priests, believers, and ANGELS) suddenly decided to commit sin for glory and profit? Some might argue it shows the corruption behind modern religion. But the general image of God and his followers are GOOD. The show throws that concept right out the window and makes them the bad guys. Honestly, the weird character personalities would have been acceptable if they didn't start out with Satan's army killing everything.


(end of spoiler)


The problems do not end here. The characters are flat. There is little to no character development making some situations far too predictable. Most characters feel like copies from other shows. One positive thing I have to say is the fact that their lack of depth made it easier to fit in with random episodes.


Enjoyment:

The review makes it sound like you cannot enjoy the show. But in reality, it can be. Someone who only enjoys heavy story lines might not, but for someone who want entertainment by watching only one or two episodes, its great. 


Do I recommend it?

Personally, I would. Though it lacks in story and character, it can be easily accessible to any type of viewers. Hardcore or not, you will get some kind of a kick out of it. But looking at the show with hard,cold facts, I wouldn't recommend it if you want something serious.

Hataraku Maou-Sama is a good choice for you if you enjoy generic modern anime releases, basically the same exact characters plastered over with a different concept for the story. The concept of the show is an interesting one, which is basically the opposite of the traditional "humans get sent into a magic world where they involve themselves in it out of a sense of duty and out of a thirst of adventure". Basically, a bunch of demons escape to the human world where they start living as humans, and grow out of magic and terrorizing and start enjoying the comfortable life Earth has to offer.(Except they weren't even that demonic to begin with)


What kept me interested in the anime was the concept and nothing else. But while it had an interesting concept, sure, it didn't explore it as much as they could through more depth to its characters and rather went with generic personalities for the characters in the show. Basically the types of characters you encounter in most new anime releases nowadays, some token average guy that looks like Kirito from Sword Art Online as the MC, but I have to give them some credit that at the very least the averageness of this guy makes sense because being average is part of a comfortable life so it makes sense they would use this type of character for this concept. What doesn't make sense is why the fuck didn't they develop on why the Demon Lord would have this personality, why he would act this way. Next up, some token tsundere who is comedically mistaken to be in a relationship with her archrival which is, really funny, we're all laughing. She calls herself hero because, yeah. Also make her a redhead, because yeah, exactly. Some girl who's whole personally is that she has a crush on the main character, she's a klutz and she has huge tits, because plot. Some overly loyal underling to the MC who's personality is "#CutForMC". And some villains that after they get defeated they're around and they're completely inoffensive and they simply, just change because, they were defeated so them being villains doesn't serve the story any purpose, so might as well make them gag characters.  Basically, the cast of every anime ever. Hell, the series is so generic that you'll encounter the generic "beach" episode, but in this situation the "beach" is an amusement park I suppose. 


What I can tell you about the story is that it does delve in the backstory of some characters but for some it doesn't at all. You don't have enough details about any of the demons and what exactly they've done and why they've done it and you're only left to wonder. There's no real clear villain, I mean, maybe the church but there's so little focus on the church they feel like total scrubs and nobody will really care much about them.  Any conflict is there just to be there. And once it gets solved it's like it never happened. The only result of the conflict itself is new characters and that's about it. If that doesn't generic I don't know what does. So due to the fact that some characters have backstory while others have none of theirs revealed it will leave you wonder exactly what happened and why they're holding back to the extent they are now and stuff like that. Like, motherfucker, he is the demon lord, he is supposed to have killed plenty of people and be treacherous. And you see him flipping burgers and you're like, he must be a kindhearted soul after some episodes? In the end, the story is basically, a guy works at McDonalds and generic characters happen. There's not much depth about anything there and every conflict falls lackluster and the character's motivations and actions are questionable. 


The art is also generic, it's basically what you'd expect from any new anime release and looks like basically every new anime ever. I'll give them some credit in the design that they have the characters talk in a different language from every language but, it sounds... as far from a language as possible. It sounds like reversed japanese if anything with weird accentuation. It goes all over the place. Otherwise the show sounds as you'd expect any other anime to sound, but that custom language will pop out sometimes.


So basically, if you like to watch generic anime which were made with the mindset of "it sells", then you will probably enjoy this anime since at the very least its very idea is I suppose original. But otherwise, there's not much else to see. If you don't like the "if it sells it's good" type of anime, by all means, avoid this. I'd say there was some potential to the show, but, its execution falls short so it can sell off.

I have not seen a single show like Hataraku Maou-sama. The anime revolves around a very original idea that has never been done before. In addition, its a hilarious anime and NEVER gets boring. The characters could not be more likeable considering that they are all differently portrayed and develop very strongly throughout the series.
The most interesting aspect of the show is how all of the main characters have a unique relationship to the main character Sadao Maou (Satan), whether it be love (Chiho), hatred (Emilia), or anything between. The plot always goes in a natural direction as well, with every episode keeping the viewerinterested in what is going on.\n\n
I recommend this anime to anyone who is looking for humorous, but also inspiring show. I’d call Hataraku Maou-sama not only one the best of 2013 animes so far, but darn-right one of the most flawless animes of all time!

I'm gonna put it in the most straight-forward manner possible: this thing is highly unparalleled when it comes to originality. 
The concept is incredibly refreshing. Satan travels to Earth after being forcibly exiled from his original world... and ends up working as a part-timer to survive in a vastly different setting from what he was used to. High jinks and hilarity ensue for Satan and the people he meets along the way. There's action. There's comedy. There's even a cute, busty girl with a huge crush on Satan tossed in there just for the sake of it. 
Suffice to say, this was a REALLY greatshow.

I think the series is just worth checking out for the premise alone. Satan, trying to dominate the fast-food through a fictional McDonald's while kinda going out with a moe blob on the side. Is it something more beside, the stupid yet ingenious premise? Sort of. The humor of the show is not too laugh-out loud. Most of the time, it just put a smile on my face, about wittiness of the humor sometimes. Some characters I thought were fun were Alciel, Satan, and Lucifer. Sadly, this series really needs a second season, since it feels incomplete. I did like it, but it's not thebest comedy for me.

solid comedy with an amazing level of back story and good steady character development. This show balanced comedy with serious moral questions and a little drama in a very smooth way, not many shows do that well, most stick to being primarily one thing or another, like a comedy where they might have a serious episode or story arc over a couple episodes but sticks to comedy the rest of the time, very few writers have the skill to mix and balance a serious overall plot with a show that has episodic short sub plots and a gag comedy front. The devil is a parttimer pulls this off though. You get the best of both worlds, each episode has a feeling of conclusion for that days antics, but you advance the main plot a little and want to see more, and the jokes keep a light tone to balance against the honestly morbid history and background of the characters involved. Overall, a very enjoyable series.

Now, on to specifics:


Story: 8

While not fresh or terribly unique, it's solid and well written.


Art: 6.5

The quality is on par with the majority of titles released at that time, it's decent, not outstanding, but not lacking in any way. Overall I rate it fair to good, but nothing stands out to give it more than that.



Sound: 5

While nothing stood out as being badly done, the music and sound effects felt generic, nothing in the way of memorable


Characters: 6

Of course, as with many anime, the characters all fall into one of the many steryotypical architectures. They have a little unique flare here and there, but their personality types have all been seen before. The real treat here is the way they play off each other, and how the types are grouped up.


Enjoyment: 7

I nearly put this at an 8, this show was very enjoyable as far as it went, but the way it just cuts off and ends with nothing in the way of a conclusion leaves you hanging.


Overall: 6.5

This needed one more season, it really did, the last episode wasn't even a proper ending, it just felt like another mid season episode. There was plenty of plot left, character development to go through, and history to explore, but none of that happened. It's obvious this was written intending far more, at a minimum another 12 to 13 episodes, but it didn't get there. A continuation would bump the first seasons score up to a solid 7 or better, but the way were left with a completely unsatisfying lack of resolution hurts the score pretty bad.


Really, it was a good show, and I had hoped for more, but as it stands, I am left somewhat conflicted. I enjoyed watching, I wanted to come away maintaining that feeling of enjoyment, but it was half done, so that enjoyment has been overshadowed by disappointment since a second season is clearly not happening. Still worth watching, but know up front that if you do like it, you will not find satisfaction in the end.

My first 10 on MAL. Absolutely perfect in every way, a fantastic display of what the anime medium is capable of. Going from laughing, to crying, to awesome fight scenes...what more can you ask for? I thought at first that the breathtaking art in the initial episode was an anomaly for a slice of life anime but oh boy, it's only a portent of things to come. If people want to ask me why I watch anime, THIS is what I'll show them. It's hard to imagine this story coming together in any other format besides anime. 
The character development and pacing are especially crispin this. They cut out all the crap that makes a series drag on, such as awkward getting to learn new surroundings episodes that you can already guess what's gonna happen. It seriously never drags, and the story moves along at a brisk space. The team did a really good job of picking out the best scenes to make you invested in characters. I felt interested in most of the characters even though they've only been in the series for two episodes. Sure, there are plot elements that, looking back on it now, seem a bit deus ex machina-ish, but really didn't seem that way in the flow of things because they helped expedite development within and between the characters. 


Music is mostly so-so. It's your typical anime OST stuff...it really doesn't belie how awesome its accompanying show is. But you really don't notice because everything else catches your attention enough. 


They also end it in absolutely the most perfect way it could have. That's not something I can say for even some of my favorite shows in the past.

I was about four episodes in when I suddenly realised what was going on. This was Season Six of 'Buffy the Vampire Slayer', but good. The notion of fantastical characters forced to endure mundane lives. But written by someone that was positively enjoying every single moment of it.
The deftness of tone, exceptional cast of characters, the never ending supply of first rate humour. The work of a man reveling in work rather than suffering from it. There are core weaknesses however, which prevent it becoming the all time hit it could have been. Story structure being number one, pacing number two. 
Yet more often thannot, the sheer joyousness of the occasion is what counts. Hence this time at least, youth wins out over experience. Now, about Season 2.\n
8.5/10

Good lord people. This is just a masterpiece. As far as comedies go, this has a perfect balance of action, drama, and comedy. Obviously it leans toward the comedy side. This anime makes me nostalgic for things I've never experienced.
The story moves at a perfect speed. Every episode is full of perfectly timed jokes that you might see in a top notch comedy series.
The whole anime is we designed, but the character art is stunning. There actually isn't anything remarkable about the art except for the character colors. Something about it didn't let me pull my eyes away.
There is nothing remarkable about the sound engineering.
Everycharacter was designed and portrayed perfectly. Loved the voices, loved the character development, loved everything.\n\n
This is a cross between a slice of life anime and an action anime with a comedic foundation. I want to relate this to Noragami, but Noragami has emotional weight that likens to the size of ... something huge. You know the part before the opening on Noragami? That part with the little joke? That's this series.\n\n
One of the best comedy anime I've ever seen.

This review includes some minor spoilers pertaining to whether some characters get together. I have labeled some sections in this review if you wish to jump to certain points.
• Summary
I enjoyed Hataraku as a whole, however it didn't hold up as much as I was hoping, earning the five I've given it. It was lacking plot-wise, but had some good backstory and moments in the show. It starts off promising, with the start setting up the premise well, keeping me amused while containing lots of interesting lore and backstory. It did not keep that up, to my disappointment. If you are going into this showhoping for anything past some funny jokes and scenarios, don't. Hataraku is a bunch of fluff with some interesting lore, along with amusing moments and drip-fed hints of plot sprinkled throughout that just barely get you to the end of the show.


• Story/Plot


Plot is very lacking from this show. The first half or so of the season was a good time, containing many amusing moments and drawing me in with interesting backstory and good characters. It's rather a shame, because it goes through a bit of a dry spell story-wise in the middle of the show, and I had to take a short break due to boredom, before coming back refreshed. Once I had slogged through the dry spell, I was hoping Hataraku would pull me back in with some good character development or story continuation. But the end of the show completely lacks any resolutions at all. The final episode was basically just yet another fluff piece for ninety-percent of it, with a very slight bit of story in there. In the end, the antagonists were kind of defeated but not really, and even if we consider them properly defeated, Ente Isla still had plenty of other enemies that could come through a gate easily. 


This is listed as a romance, but no relationships are ever formed. The primary possible romantic partner, Chiho, clearly likes the main character, Maou. That's all fine and dandy, except he acts completely oblivious and the relationship goes nowhere. There is a vague implication that Maou and Emi, the Hero, could become closer in some way, but this also goes nowhere. By the end of the show no relationships have been formed what-so-ever.


So after watching thirteen episodes, what has changed? Well, some characters were added to the cast, but that's basically it. Maou is still in the same apartment working the same job, doing the same stuff, Emi is still in the same apartment, working the same job, doing the same stuff, Chi is still at her parents, working the same job... look, you get it. Nothing was accomplished in the entirety of the thirteen episodes. I get this is a comedy, but it gets a little old watching an entire season of nothing, as the good jokes were all used up in the first half of the show.


• Characters


The characters had some good depth overall, but they suffer from the plot never moving. The show kept teasing me with signs of Emi trying to compare the human, Maou, to the demon, Satan, and this was explored a little. But even though we had the start of this plotline it was randomly cut off by someone barging in and it never continued. So by the end, while Emi has realised that Maou is a decent person and not the evil dark lord, it was never explained why he isn't evil or if he was evil before but had an ulterior motive. This was one of the most intriuging parts of the show for me, and it even dangles it in front of me but then never continues! I am so frustrated by this fact. If it weren't for the crutch of the plot, I think these characters would really be able to shine. That never happened, however.


• Other Thoughts & Wrap Up


The animation and sound were good, I never had anything to complain about, though nothing stuck out to me to make them exceptional. I doubt you will be disappointed by anything on the technical side while watching this.


If you want a bit of fun seeing a lord of demons living in modern-day Japan with no real story to speak of, this is the show for you. It wasn't bad, and it was one of the funnier shows I've seen in a while. But for me, the lack of story was just too much to properly recommend this show. I was disappointed by how the potential shown at first was squandered so thoroughly, and it was not the experience that I was hoping for after seeing the first episode. Ultimately, an average show. Nothing special, nothing terrible. Just... average.

The first time watching this show, I dropped it after a few episodes because I couldn’t really get past the initial scenario. The distinct personality of a ruler of a world and his general was so quickly transformed into two bland mid 20s living together and adopting mundane mannerisms like being extremely frugal, or worrying about the budget or advancing his part-time job as a McDonald's worker. It was pretty jarring and the transition felt so lazily done, like the show was expecting me to just forget it or to make up something to somehow seem like this was plausible. The second time I watchedit, I ignored this detail and found that at times it could be funny, but more in “Working!!” type scenarios in the workplace rather than anything to do with the main premise or quirk of the show. 


When the show had to go back to the initial premise of the demon lord and general being sent to the human world, it fell flat on its back. The action and drama like when he faced this demon that was sort of disrupting the human world was very b-movie like with shitty one-liners after the demon lord finally releases his power like “C’mon I’ll be late to work.” They try to fit in some drama or persecution to make the demon lord seem like a good guy and that people are just judging him because he’s the demon lord but the main MC is so blase about everything and what the show is doing is so obvious that I ended up just being annoyed. Plot is just thrown around like nothing, like just something to fill up space. For example they try to go through the back story of Emilia, the hero, and it sort of gets resolved(?) with the demon lord making some sort of half-baked apology (like I think it was a few words) after hearing her pour her heart out in front of him. 


 I really couldn’t take it and I think the show would’ve been better if they already had the demon lord in the world from a young age or maybe had him fuse with a college student during the transfer to the human world. Or maybe simply focus on the humor and working part instead of 

trying to do too much by also having a story. As the show is, it wasn’t enjoyable and at time infuriating.

This is a pretty funny show, but if I had to critique it, the main problem would be the inconsistent characters. The demon lord, his servant, and his general Lucifer, (who by the way killed THOUSANDS of people) were reduced to nothing but boring and cliché characters by the end. How does Lucifer a merciless general that thinks nothing of death just become a NEET with absolutely zero intention to go back to heaven? I know I'm kinda nitpicking the show, and I didn't really notice these problems while i was watching the show and I don't think that should stop you from watching it.
Alsoif you watch this show, I think it's a lot better if you imagine this as the backstory of the demon king in beelzebub xD

Went into this expecting a comedy as it is often recommended as one. Definitely did not feel like a comedy. Sure, there were funny moments, but it felt more like a weird shounen fantasy action/romantic slice of life hybrid. 
What I expected was for the plot to revolve around the Devil working in a McDonalds. With emphasis on the workplace as the main setting and the daily shenanigans or acclimation process to be the comedy. 
The dynamic between the Devil and the other characters is endearing and comedic at times, but overall The Devil is a Part Timer! is nothing to write home about. Inmy opinion it would have been more worthwhile to hone either the comedy or shounen elements to this story because I think trying to do both was a miss.

I saw the synopsis and thoght to myself "This can be one of my favorite anime ever!" The devil trying to conquer our world starting by working on Mc Donald's, prfect right? RIGHT? (That was what I tought...)
Story:
Like I said before, the synopsis is perfect for a comedy show, but it sudenly turns into a romace/harem anime, a genre that I don't like that much, but that isn't the worst problem here...
Art:
Nothing to talk about, it works really well.
Sound:

Character:

What about Emilia? The tsundere "heroin" that fell in love with Maou, come on, she is the HEROIN and Maou is the DEVIL for me, their goals are really clear and there is nothing about felling in love with you enemy...\n\n
Enjoyment:\n
This anime has a lot of funny moments I can't lie, but the plot and the characters simply dosen't fit with the propose of the show.

This felt so unfinished ... Interesting beginning, but then (after going through gate), total change of action of MC ? WITH NO EXPLANATION ? Seemingly not going back to his old ways even at end of series (even when he learned how to regain demon juice)... This needs 2. series (story vise) so bad, I could not enjoi it ... (F*CK SLICE OF LIFE ASPECT, drop it... or maybe I am slace of life hater ? ). 
Humour : 	meh...
Art: 		quite good
Story: 		It really needs 2. series
As you can see, the main future of this is story which starts very interesting ... but then itswas left untouched for rest of the series. So dont watch it for story... Watch it only if you are able to enjoy this kind of humor ... drawn out ... and somewhat not that funny...\n

I'd really love to give this show an 8+... but I can't. Here's why (I'll keep it short and simple):
- Comedy: very good premise and a fertile ground to have hilarious scenes. There are some which I was so excited about, but they were never exploited enough.
- Characters: all so interesting in their own way, but so underdeveloped! Maou would be one of my favourite male MC if they had put more flavour into it. Maybe show us more colours, he seems so black and white! No progression from Evil to Hero - it seems like it happened overnight. The characters need more depth sowe can empathize with them.


- Story: again, such a good premise and so underdeveloped. Even the whole Orba and Sariel plot was so... insipid. No actual build up, little context... 


- Soundtrack: I liked the soundtrack, no brilliant, but fits the story well.


What makes one come back for the next episode? Interest, wanting to know more, wanting to enjoy the next good laugh. I finished this because I gave it one chance after another and the premise was interesting. But I was not particularly caught on it.


I'd give it a 7 if 7 was "Slight above average". The plot is interesting, it was a nice pilot episode, I laughed a lot, but we need more scenes either developing the romance, with more comedy into them, or that develop characters and the actual story.


I'll be waiting for the second season in hopes it will get better...

This was a pretty light and quick watch. I wasn't expecting much of the story line, but it surprisingly turned up to be something.
I was intrigued that the main character was supposedly this evil guy - the devil. But he was such an ordinary man living in the modern world. Of course that is all thanks to the modern world not having much magic that the devil needed to get back to his realm. As other characters come into play throughout the episodes and more situations happen, it's really ironic how it ended up to be more of a "life lesson-type thing" because it's moralswith the devil? Haha.\n\n
It wasn't much else to it - just something simple and to the point most of the time. But it was definitely enough to make a pretty good anime. It was just a fun one.

If Dante from Devil May Cry has a child, or let's just imagine if Satan was in fact a cool guy in person, then meet Maou Sadao.
Hataraku Maou-Sama! or The Devil is a Part Timer, is a 90% Slice-of-Life, 10% Action anime that focuses about the daily life of the Demon King, Satan, who forces to give up the battle against Emilia the Hero and went to the present day, Japan. At first, he wanted to rule the world starting in Japan, but his evil plan suddenly came to stop as Satan... or Maou Sadao in Japanese Name, changes his life as he started towork at MgRonalds, and met so many friends in Japan.


The title says it all, The Devil is a Part Timer, was at first, a dark story about the devils against the group of good guys and angels and the churches and the priests to stop the devil's primary objective... To rule the whole Ente Isla. But, thanks to a woman's bravery named, Emilia the Hero, the Devil named Satan and his sidekick, Alsiel, left Ente Isla to take a little breathing.


But, when the portal lead to the present day, Tokyo, Japan, the two then started to plan something evil against the whole country and even the whole world. And their first plan, Satan... or Maou Sadao, started to work in MgRonalds as he believed that he's going to conquer the world as a part-timer. While Alsiel, or Shirou Ashiya on the other hand, is still serving the Demon King as a house... uh... househusband? That's sounds ugly to hear... Oh... let's just say he's just a Servant.... Pardon my English.


The Story in Hataraku Maou-sama is quite a great story though, with a lot of comedy and keeping the Slice-of-life genre a little less boring thanks to Maou Sadao's comedic approach and jokes. He somehow reminds me of Dante from Devil May Cry due to his comedy though. But as for the battle sequences here, it's not really that important here though. I mean, it's best that if they stay in the Slice-of-life rather than the short battles. Because the battles were not to memorable and they just make the battle sequences became a bit more hilarious and fun because of Maou's coolness and punchlines.


Also, there's some fan service here in other episodes as well. I'm not into those kinds of things though, because that could mess my reputation as I watch this anime. I mean, yeah, I get it, Chiho's boobs are big, and I also saw Emilia's bra on her see-through clothes thanks to her sweat. I GET IT! SHE'S FLAT WHILE CHIHO'S BOOBS IS AS THE SIZE OF A FUCKING MELONS... I GET IT!!! JUST DON'T POINT WHERE ARE THOSE CHESTS LOCATED YOU CAMERAMAN HENTAI-DESU!! (ehem)pardon my weeaboo...


The character development seems it's very well written here. I really do like how they changed when every episode came along. Including some of the Ente Isla heroes and villain who came to Earth and how they were drastically changed thanks to the present setting of the story.


Also, the language when they were on Ente Isla is the very first anime that I've seen so far to use a unique language. It kinda sounds like it came from Germany or somewhere in Europe. Also, I don't know how they could handle that, despite that they are Japanese and they are having some trouble to say it. Kudos for them.


To wrap my review, I'd definitely recommend you guys to watch this anime. If you're not a fan of some "Fairy Tail" cliches, then go watch this anime. It's a very funny anime for you to watch. I guarantee it!!

My reviews are based on 5 major distinctions: Art, Plot, Characters, Music, and Flow.  I rate each category with a simple 3 point scale.  
0 = Doesn't meet expectations
1 = Meets expectations
2 = Clearly exceeds Expectations
Intro: Hataraku Maou-Sama! is a different style of anime that isn't based in a school format.  The story is conveyed between two separate universes interacting with each other through a portal.  A world consisting of magic in a medieval setting on one side, and modern day Japan on the other.  The anime tries to mix drama with comedy and romance.  It is difficult toachieve a balance between the three and actually achieving it would propel this show out of obscurity if done properly.  The review will now begin.


Art: 2.

The drawings are well done in the background as well as the many characters that appear.  The main characters such as Maou and Emi are both drawn with great detail in their civilian clothing as well as work attire.  I enjoyed the facial expressions throughout the series since they gave the audience a sense of the atmosphere be it light hearted and comedic, or dark and full of drama.  Reading dialogue only gives us basic information.  The characters have to also show us the situation through their expressions.  The artists perfected this craft.  That is why I gave the art a perfect score.


Plot: 1.

The plot wasn't too interesting after reading the synopsis because it was made to look like a fantasy, action series when it actually wasn't.  I am not complaining about it now since I watched the series.  From a bystander's point of view, the story doesn't seem like it would work at being an action or drama.  The comedy doesn't come until a little later in the story and the first episode doesn't convey a light hearted atmosphere until much later.  People who would watch the series for the action or drama would get turned off after the first episode when it's almost dropped.  The comedy doesn't come until later and by then, the people watching the series for that would be almost turned off by the middle of the first episode.  I am not saying the plot is bad or anything; I am just implying that the sudden change from an action, drama to a comedy might turn some people off at first glance.  I would like to say that the rest of the series plays out very well with the jokes, and conversations through the rest of the episodes.  There are some problems that pertain to the overall plot including the portals that keep allowing people to transfer between worlds later on in the series.  There is also an issue with the goal of the story near the end when nothing happens during a few of the episodes.  With a certain goal being implied in the beginning, I wouldn't enjoy it stagnating near the end when it was almost over.  Overall, the plot is good but not great.  There could be some things that could make it better but I still enjoyed it.


Characters: 2.

The characters are the greatest aspect of this anime.  There is a wide range of personalities involved here and their conversations between one another bring out the positives as well as negatives in each one of them.  Maou's carefree attitude in one scene transitions beautifully to a hard working member of society in the next.  I consider Chiho to be comedy relief because of her boring personality.  The story uses her mainly as a love interest for our true main character.  There is nothing wrong with that since the story itself is considered a comedy, but she could have more emotions to her personality other than love.  Ashiya is another character that is used for comedy relief.  I personally love every phrase he says on the show because his jokes aren't stupid or juvenile.  Emi, our main heroine has a wide range of emotions that work pretty well for a main heroine.  She changes from a nice person to a rabid dog and back instantly as the scene requires from her and she does it flawlessly.  I enjoyed all of the conversations between her and Maou because they seemed so real.  That is the greatest thing about the characters here.  They are real and full. 


Music: 2.

The OP and ED are both nice but not too memorable.  Most of the music during the episodes were light hearted and very Seinfeld-like.  Since the story was mainly a comedy, the songs definitely achieved their purpose.  I download the OST and listened to the songs mainly to try and examine all of them directly.  There were a couple songs that stood out but they were only played during the action scenes.  Overall, the music was nice and fitting for most of the scenes that they played over.


Flow: 1.

The story has a problem with its flow.  It transcends between light hearted to drama filled with each episode.  Most of the episodes start with a nice happy tone and beautifully end with some sort of drama.  I didn't mind that in the beginning but it began to bore me near the end of the series.  Some of the episodes didn't progress the plot at all and felt like a filler.  The entire story seemed to change from one episode to another and that could be considered off putting by some people. 


Overall: 8.

I personally enjoyed this anime even with some of the faults that I found with it.  The jokes and conversations between the characters were brilliantly written and spoken through the entire series.  The plot left something to be desired but still kept it's importance on one major aspect, comedy.  The drama interchanged with the comedy quickly and beautifully.  The art was done perfectly as well with each character drawn well enough to not notice any discrepancies.  The music gave us the atmosphere for each scene whether it was supposed to be light hearted or filled with drama.  The flow had some issues towards the end but ended on a perfect note.  I enjoyed this anime a lot and will re-watch it again when it comes out on DVD.

Hataraku Maou-sama!, a pretty good comedy anime, probably one of the tops for the spring season of 2013. I first watched this anime when my friend said that the main female character wants the main male character's D. I was hyped in a matter of seconds. As a result, I decided to dedicate my god-like, ethereal, divine, holistic, precious time to watch this thing. If you want to pursue McDonalds as your career, i suggest you watCH this. 
Genres:
1) Comedy: The comedy in this anime is marvelous, you cannot not laugh at least once in an episode unless you fell asleep at the first minute(not likely). The transition of being compelled to accommodate in an unknown realm from yours and different world means that it is almost definite that struggling to cope with the current modality and being transferred into a new world is what makes Hataraku enjoyable and most fun to watch. 


2) Romance: The romance in this anime is not on par to the comedy however, there are signs of some decent potential romance but sadly sometimes ruined by the frequent added comedy throughout an episode which denies any possible further romance, to the point Emi wants Maou's D. Hard to achieve, but worth achieving and living for. There are many bonds and relationships evident in Hataraku and so no relationships or ships are predictable. The relationships of Ashiya, Maou, Chiho, Emi, Urushihara and Suzuno all develop and interlink, to the point where we cry when Emi does not get the D off of Maou. 


3) Action/Fantasy: The action is quite superb and the animation of the fight scenes are so good it makes you suck 17 Ds in one second, i mean so good it makes you feel like you are watching some 3D thing. Also, the world of this anime is really unique, demons and the demonic world coexist with  humans and Earth. 


Conclusion: A very good anime for its comedy and just by looking at this review, i assume you have shted bricks already. The hype!

Well this is my first review on an anime series, but I'll try my best!
Hataraku Maou-sama! caught me off guard of how well and hilarious it is. Every episode left me wanting for more. By the time I finished, I just realized how much time I used up haha.
Story (9/10)/ Enjoyment (10/10)
Just a few episodes in just got me hooked in. Every episode left me curious (heh hyouka reference) that I would just simply keep watching. Hataraku's comedic sense just amazed me. I found myself laughing in every episode. However, there are those cliche parts, but not every anime is perfect. 
Art/Sound (9/10)
The artwork andsound are perfectly fine. Nothing that I know of annoyed me when I was watching it. The sound is placed correctly to the point that I was able to foreshadow something funny, epic, etc. The artwork is pretty cute and hilarious at times.\n\n
Character (9/10)\n
It's hard for me to not spoil this part xD. Anyways, a demon king turns into an ordinary human. Think about it, how would he react? Well watch it lol. The character development is so.. sudden, and that is not a bad thing. It provides comedic sense and just fits in with the amusing storyline.\n\n
Overall (9/10)\n
I personally enjoyed Hataraku. It contains a great storyline which fits in the character development. The Art and Sound are created nicely with the story. These aspects makes Hataraku a wonderful anime to watch as I watched all the episodes in one sitting xD.\n\n
Thanks for reading~\n\n

At the beginning, it is the story of a rotten demon king trying to take over the world, now becomes a story of demon king now a human with no more powers to do his evil deeds. This anime is full of comedy and surprises such as how someone who gets what he wants by force is now working to pay taxes! Even though he is a demon king.  it shows how being a human being can change someones heart. It represents our hard work and humanity, that we must all take responsibility of ourselves and our actions, and how one must notjudge a book by it's cover. Later on in the anime, the most reliable people and people who didn't need help at all now start to realize that you really can't do everything on your own, no matter who you are, how you were born, what particular raise or bloodline you are, it's never enough to be alone and self-relying. the anime shows how an old rivalry now becomes a comedic love-hate of friendship, but now the demon king realizes that everything he does it's now his responsibility to take care of it, and how being human can mold your heart. If you like  magic and partially romance, comedy and inspiring anime, this is truly one for you. - RxR

This series caught me by surprise, and within the first episode I was caught up in a world of comedy, demons, and the struggles of the real world.
Hataraku Maou-sama! Is about a world known as Ente Isle, where to us humans, exist all what we see as fiction, this includes demons,angels, and magic. The Demon Lord known as The Overlord Satan seeks to widen his empire, but is soon pushed back by a hero, Emilia who is half human and angel. Using her sacred powers, and her sword, The Better-Half, Maou (The Overlord Satan) is forced to retreat with his subordinate Ashiya. Together they landin Japan to find themselves stranded, broke,and powerless. Maou must now learn to live in the human world as a model citizen to survive. 


Story: The story IMO completely depends on the characters, it isn't an anime with a major overbearing plot that everything revolves around, but one that revolves around the characters, and their actions. So including the characters, I'll have to say that the story progressed quite nicely, this anime wasn't entirely a shounen, romance based, yet, in another point of view, a comedy based on Maou's struggles in Japan. The characters were all introduced quite nicely and each were provided with their own background information, none at all were too overbearing. The main reason this anime thrives is the interactions the characters have with each other. Starting from Maou, the ex-ruler of Ente Isle, but still the Overlord known as Satan, is a slightly oblivious, yet cunning, and powerful character. As the main character, he fills his role quite well in this slice of life themed anime. The comedy that ensues around Maou because of his peculiar personality that I cannot relate to many other anime allows for laughs to occur. Along with Maou, his trusty subordinate, Ashiya, his loyalty to Maou,and concern for their financial affairs in the human world also allow for good plot development in their social standings, and also supports Maou, which in turn affects the character development that happens to both of them. A standard character development of dramatic characters is seen, which is, "the evil bad boy gets soft and kind" sort of thing, but it is done in a unique way. Character conflict is also a major part of the story, either with the fabled fallen angel Lucifer, or the hero Emilia, comedy seems to be the main focus of this anime, and I'll have to say FUNmation did a fantastic job.The aspect of real world troubles are also very good additions in the anime, that also contribute to more comedy that I found in Hatakaru Maou-sama! The financial troubles of holding down a job produces a unique type of style of comedy that I have yet to see. Keep in mind that anything above a score of 5 on MAL is considered fine or good. Hataraku Maou-sama! certainly deserves this high score. 


Art and Sound: I've never had to complain about the art of an anime, (unless it's from like... the 1990's, then I just can't watch it), nonetheless being from the most recent season of completion, the art wasn't too sharp to enhance every detail but did a fine job of balancing the smooth aspects of a slice of life genre, and action that occurs from character conflict. The sound complimented the story quite well,the OP and ED were enjoyable, yet during the anime, the music IMO failed to stand out and say "download me". However that failure of attraction didn't detract from the anime as a whole.


Enjoyment and Overall: I thoroughly enjoyed this anime, and while keeping this review short (I hope I didn't spoil too much, feel free to comment complain if I did XD.) This anime definitely deserves a look if you are looking for some major laughs and some romantic comedy. While including those soft slice of life aspects, it also provides that shouneny action stuff for the other type of anime lovers out there. Be sure to check Hataraku Maou-Sama! out if you also enjoyed similar anime such as Blood Lad, Date a Live, Oreigaru, and Beelzebub. 


Thanks for reading,

-Nebarto

The start is typical and cliche, we have a demon lord oppressing humans, we have a hero slowly rising against him. So what is new? Well the very end of the demon lords plunders in his world is the very start of the story for both sides. The hero follows the demon lord and his right hand man as he retreats to Japan! From then on its a totally enexpected and fun ride as the hero slowly begans to see a new side of the demon lord complete with a high school girl sidekick, and new companions from either side to cause some mischief inour world. And as the days go by getting the fuel to go back home doesn't seem to get any easier ith all the ruckus they have to go through so a part time job is essential fro survival! The unknown world of Japan fascinates our demons and this new side of the enemy perplexes our hero? This could only end in laughter believe me =)

THIS WAS THE FIRST COMEDY ANIME I WATCHED.
Before I watched this anime, I was much more into drama filled anime. I saw that this show was getting good reviews, so I watched it, then I bought it on blu ray, then I watched it two more times.
STORY 8: Why do I give this an 8? Well, because it didn't end, I love a good ending, and hate a bad ending, but with this I got neither, but this show was so good I had to give it an 8
CHARACTERS 10: Which characters to I hate in this anime.... Welp... Not a M$&)&7$&&)7$ one. I lovethese characters, and even more than that, I love how these characters interact with eachother. Each has his or her own personality that is interesting to watch, so when the story focuses on a specific character, it's always enjoyable, no matter the character.\n\n

“Hataraku Maou-sama!” is a generic shounen comedy with a hint of romance that has a very interesting premise and breaks away from common stereotypes in terms of plot. However, the executions was lackluster as evident from glaringly obvious plot holes and weak characters.
Story 6/10
As I said before, “Hataraku Maou-sama!” definitely has one of the more unique premises among most shounen animes. I’ll try not to spoil too much. It is set in a fantasy world where supposedly a huge war is taking place between the humans and the demons, and like in any typical RPG game, a hero blessed with divine powers journeys to thedemon king’s domicile to engage in the final boss battle. However, in the final seconds before the demon king’s defeat, he creates a portal to take him and his chief general to another world in order to regroup…modern day Tokyo. He then discovers he is powerless and then decides to attempt to return to his original world while working part-time at McDonalds. It then plays the expected card of having the demon king amazed by how modern people live. This interesting premise however is one of the show’s only redeeming qualities, as while the first few episodes honestly had me laughing, it only goes downhill from there.

While working at McDonalds, the “demon king” lives an honest life, does community service, and is a model citizen. The biggest plot hole slowly, but surely surfaces. How on earth does the power-hungry conqueror of lands, the very incarnation of evil, suddenly become a shounen protagonist in the course of one episode!? Not once does this anime care to explain this, as upon his arrival in Tokyo he automatically transforms from a dark lord to a caring and honest young man. No proper explanation is given, and throughout the anime they expect us to simply accept this. In the beginning, they spoke a strange made-up language (from their old world) but suddenly become fluent in Japanese. This plot hole alone…isn’t really a big deal but what really bugged me is how they alternated between it at time for no apparent reason.


Art, Animation and Sound 7/10

Nothing very memorable, but nothing very bad either.


Characters 6/10

The term “generic” can be used to aptly describe the entire cast. We have the red-haired tsundere, the orange-haired genki girl, a loyal servant who is constantly amazed by his master’s kindness and of course, the protagonist with barely any personality. The girls are quite annoying, and the servant is forgotten in the second half of the anime for REALLY stupid reasons. There is some character development though. For instance, the demon king, the main protagonist ends up developing from a genuinely interesting character into a boring male lead reminiscent of most male harem protagonists. There are also 2 characters that are introduced in one episode and even appear in the intro, but barely appear at all throughout the entire anime, with one of them only appearing in like one episode. By the end of the series, I didn’t like most of the characters.


Enjoyment 8/10

I have to admit though, despite the show’s many flaws, and the fact that I have been quite critical about it, it was quite enjoyable to watch. The first few episodes were really funny, as they focused mainly on the better characters, the demon king and his servant. Their initial reactions to Japanese culture and their various attempts to save money were hilarious. It was also great to see the demon king grow some balls every few episodes and beat someone up. 


Overall 7/10

“Hataraku Maou-sama!” is definitely one of the more creative shounen animes out there, which I liked, but is really nothing more than average. If you like stupid humor there are better alternatives (baka to test), and if you like decent plots and character development in addition to the slice of life aspect there are many better animes to choose from as well. However, this is definitely a refreshing take on the genre is quite enjoyable as well. Just don’t watch it with high expectations.

kxReview: Hataraku Maou-sama
Hataraku started very well with tons of action and fairly good comedy but it just doesn't have a focus in my opinion. The comedy here is well done and you'll find yourself chuckling here and there. What really really disappointed me however,is just how the story tries to fit so much and ends up not fitting anything. Example, they introduce 2 characters and just never used them for anything but a small dialog partly in the end.Another example, the introduce a bad guy but they didn't explain his motivations that well, like the writers just needed a bad guy to exist for noapparent reason. They also underdeveloped the main cast by introducing new characters before the development occurs. It was like getting cake then being served another cake before I could taste the first cake.And then another cake is given, and now I have 3 cakes and another cake comes and I just don't know whats happening and I can't pay for any of these cakes and *cough cough...(Lets get back on track) That kinda pissed me off since most of the characters would have been interesting because they aren't one dimensional. Maou is a Dark Lord but hes not as evil as the people in his old world think he is, but we never got to know why he was like that in the first place. Or why and for what the end-game bad guy wanted to do what he did to Emilia. It just felt lacking. Don't get me wrong however. Hataraku isn't a bad anime. I just wished it was better executed.


As for the ending, i thought it would go for a what I call, sizzle ending. Sizzle ending is when they end the fight scenes and main plots the episode before, and then try to cover some loose holes and end some of the minor plot points on the final episodes. Like cutting of the loose ends and showing what the characters are going to do now that the main conflict is over. Hataraku's ending was kinda what I call filler. I didn't cover anything and I just wasn't what I wanted.


I recommend Hataraku Mauo-sama if your looking for a good comedy with fun characters. Just don't expect to much for what it seems to go for in the first episode.
